• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.

• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).

• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.1 — Org Chart v0→v3 (Alpha, GA, Multi‑city)

§7.1 — Org Chart v0→v3 (Alpha, GA, Multi‑city)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Define the sequencing of teams as we scale from one squad to multiple squads and a platform lane.
• Clarify which surfaces are owned by which squads at each phase.
• Avoid premature specialization without starving critical lanes (Money/Tax, Trust/Safety).

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• v0: single squad; v1: Core App + Growth; v2: add Money/Tax and Studios; v3: add SRE and Data as platform orgs.
• DRI matrix: page → owner; admin panel → owner; city → GM.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Phase milestones hit on time; reduced cross‑team blockers; clear ownership of incident response; predictable on‑call coverage.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Matrix confusion; orphaned surfaces; mismatched incentives; inadequate platform investment; on‑call burnout.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Org v0/v1/v2 posters published; DRI matrix live; incident commander rotation named; GM role for city ops defined.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — ACH returns spike: How Finance and Support coordinate, which macros they use, and how the buyer‑fee discount copy changes temporarily.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Promotions abuse attempt: How invalid‑click detection works, how credits are auto‑applied, and when Trust pauses paid delivery for an account.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Background check adverse action: FCRA steps, Smart Docs templates, notice timing, and how the reputation score decays and recovers.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — LBG refund split: How a partial refund on the studio leg coexists with a completed talent leg, and how amended receipts are generated.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Content safety override: Artistic nude flagged by the classifier; Trust review, override with reason, and model’s Safe‑Mode default.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Tax outage during checkout: Allowlist behavior, buyer banner copy, deferred quotes, and daily reconciliation safeguards.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — On‑call handoff: Messaging degradation detected by synthetics; playbook steps; escalation tree; status page language.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — City‑2 gating: What evidence we require to open promotions and tax in the next city, and how we staff support hours in local time.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.2 — Headcount Ramp & Budget (by Function & Phase)

§7.2 — Headcount Ramp & Budget (by Function & Phase)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Plan hires that unlock the next milestone without over‑staffing.
• Map headcount to revenue milestones and cost envelopes.
• Keep contractors in low‑leverage lanes; hire for durable ownership in high‑leverage lanes.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Phased adds: FE/BE for Core App; BE for Money/Tax; BE for Promotions; SRE after Beta; Ops hires for Support & T&S.
• Budget guardrails: infra+data ≤ 15% GMV; CAC budgets tied to city KPIs.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Burn multiple < plan; hiring velocity meets targets; support FRT/FRR in SLA; engineering operating time ≤ 30%.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Hiring ahead of need; over‑rotation on contractors; hidden spend in data/infra; untracked CAC in founding cities.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Headcount plan approved quarterly; offer templates ready; recruiting pipeline metrics reported weekly.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.3 — Hiring Pipeline & Interview Loops (Scorecards per Role)

§7.3 — Hiring Pipeline & Interview Loops (Scorecards per Role)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Install a repeatable, bias‑aware hiring process with strong scorecards.
• Evaluate for ship‑and‑operate behavior, not only code craft.
• Keep the bar high on writing and policy awareness.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Loops: PM (problem→tests), Eng (systems), Eng (product depth), Design (UX), T&S/Finance (policy sense), Founder panel.
• Work samples: architecture sketch; admin UX rationale; spec writing.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Time‑to‑offer; on‑site to offer rate; on‑call readiness; new hire ramp speed; predictive validity (6‑month).

Top risks & mitigations:
• Loop sprawl; unstructured interviews; skills mismatch; over‑index on prestige; lack of documentation tests.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Scorecards published; structured questions bank; candidate briefing pack; decision rubric with veto rules.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — ACH returns spike: How Finance and Support coordinate, which macros they use, and how the buyer‑fee discount copy changes temporarily.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Promotions abuse attempt: How invalid‑click detection works, how credits are auto‑applied, and when Trust pauses paid delivery for an account.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Background check adverse action: FCRA steps, Smart Docs templates, notice timing, and how the reputation score decays and recovers.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — LBG refund split: How a partial refund on the studio leg coexists with a completed talent leg, and how amended receipts are generated.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Content safety override: Artistic nude flagged by the classifier; Trust review, override with reason, and model’s Safe‑Mode default.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Tax outage during checkout: Allowlist behavior, buyer banner copy, deferred quotes, and daily reconciliation safeguards.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — On‑call handoff: Messaging degradation detected by synthetics; playbook steps; escalation tree; status page language.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — City‑2 gating: What evidence we require to open promotions and tax in the next city, and how we staff support hours in local time.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.4 — Onboarding Playbooks (Eng, Product, Ops, Support)

§7.4 — Onboarding Playbooks (Eng, Product, Ops, Support)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Compress time‑to‑impact for new hires while guarding safety and money flows.
• Make runbooks, flags, and admin tools first‑week experiences.
• Teach city‑gating and experiment ethics early.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Week‑by‑week plan: docs → sandboxes → shadowing → supervised changes → independent flags.
• Playbooks per role: Eng, PM, Design, Support, Trust, Finance.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Ramp to first merged PR/flag flip; progression to on‑call; comprehension quizzes on policy and safety; audit of first admin actions.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Paper onboarding; no admin access; cowboy changes; missing safety drills; no understanding of receipts/tax.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Onboarding checklists; sandbox credentials; practice incidents; mentor assignments; 30‑60‑90 plans.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.5 — On‑Call Rotations & Incident Roles (SEV Matrix, Pager Rules)

§7.5 — On‑Call Rotations & Incident Roles (SEV Matrix, Pager Rules)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Establish humane rotations with clear roles: IC, Comms, Ops, Eng on‑call.
• Define SEV levels, SLAs, and kill‑switch authority.
• Run quarterly disaster drills and weekly synthetics.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Pager hygiene; follow‑the‑sun vs US‑only; SEV definitions; comms templates; status page policy; feature flag recipes.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• MTTA/MTTR by SEV; incident rate declining; zero Sev‑0 unpaged; follow‑up completion rate.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Alert fatigue; ownership confusion; shadow incidents; slow rollbacks; unsafe changes under pressure.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ On‑call calendar; escalation tree; SEV matrix; comms scripts; drill schedule; blameless PIR template.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — ACH returns spike: How Finance and Support coordinate, which macros they use, and how the buyer‑fee discount copy changes temporarily.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Promotions abuse attempt: How invalid‑click detection works, how credits are auto‑applied, and when Trust pauses paid delivery for an account.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Background check adverse action: FCRA steps, Smart Docs templates, notice timing, and how the reputation score decays and recovers.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — LBG refund split: How a partial refund on the studio leg coexists with a completed talent leg, and how amended receipts are generated.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Content safety override: Artistic nude flagged by the classifier; Trust review, override with reason, and model’s Safe‑Mode default.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Tax outage during checkout: Allowlist behavior, buyer banner copy, deferred quotes, and daily reconciliation safeguards.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — On‑call handoff: Messaging degradation detected by synthetics; playbook steps; escalation tree; status page language.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — City‑2 gating: What evidence we require to open promotions and tax in the next city, and how we staff support hours in local time.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.6 — Vendor Management (SLAs, Runbooks, Escalation)

§7.6 — Vendor Management (SLAs, Runbooks, Escalation)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Treat every vendor as an adapter with contracts, metrics, and failover plans.
• Avoid lock‑in by versioning and parallelizing migrations where prudent.
• Map every vendor event into our event schema to protect analytics and ops.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• SLA registers; sandbox tests; webhook signature checks; token rotation; alternative providers list.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Uptime vs credit recovery; failover drill success; mean time to vendor escalation; coverage of adapter monitoring.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Opaque vendor outages; raw webhook dependencies; stale tokens; missing audit of external calls.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Adapter runbooks; escalation contacts; quarterly reviews; green/yellow/red health dashboard.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.

• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.7 — Outsource vs In‑House Matrix (What/When/How to Switch)

§7.7 — Outsource vs In‑House Matrix (What/When/How to Switch)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Buy for commodity lanes; build for differentiation and policy control.
• Switch intentionally with dual‑write or shadow modes; cut scope rather than rush rewrites.
• Preserve business continuity and analytics parity during transitions.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Decision matrix: payments vs tax vs IDV vs content safety vs social metrics vs messaging vs deliverables hosting.
• Techniques: strangler patterns; event shims; gold standard checks.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Switch success rate; no analytics drift; limited downtime; cost or capability gains realized.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Big‑bang rewrites; frozen features; data loss; unmeasured parity; team thrash.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ RFC templates; migration checklist; parity dashboards; rollback plans; success criteria defined upfront.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — ACH returns spike: How Finance and Support coordinate, which macros they use, and how the buyer‑fee discount copy changes temporarily.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Promotions abuse attempt: How invalid‑click detection works, how credits are auto‑applied, and when Trust pauses paid delivery for an account.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Background check adverse action: FCRA steps, Smart Docs templates, notice timing, and how the reputation score decays and recovers.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — LBG refund split: How a partial refund on the studio leg coexists with a completed talent leg, and how amended receipts are generated.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Content safety override: Artistic nude flagged by the classifier; Trust review, override with reason, and model’s Safe‑Mode default.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Tax outage during checkout: Allowlist behavior, buyer banner copy, deferred quotes, and daily reconciliation safeguards.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — On‑call handoff: Messaging degradation detected by synthetics; playbook steps; escalation tree; status page language.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — City‑2 gating: What evidence we require to open promotions and tax in the next city, and how we staff support hours in local time.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

§7.8 — Performance, Growth, and Training Ladders

§7.8 — Performance, Growth, and Training Ladders

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Define expectations and growth paths for Eng, Product, Design, Data, Support, and T&S.
• Reward outcomes (safe, reversible shipping; measurable marketplace impact).
• Make training part of the operating calendar (security, FCRA, tax, experiments).

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Ladders: IC and Manager tracks; examples tied to our surfaces (e.g., shipping change‑orders v2 safely).
• Calibration and promotion committee; peer feedback cadence; mentoring paths.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Internal mobility; promotion rates; training completion; support handoff quality; incident reduction after training.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Title inflation; opaque promotions; skill gaps; lack of training budget; burnout.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Ladder PDFs; promotion rubric; training calendar; mentoring assignments; calibration notes archived.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).
• Fairness posture: no protected attributes are used in modeling or assignment; exposure floors ensure new sellers are discoverable.
• Security: least‑privilege RBAC for admin roles (§4.14.1); PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive actions; immutable audits.
• City gating: risky changes (promotions inventory, tax expansion, studios deposits) are rolled out city‑by‑city with measurable acceptance gates.
• Close‑the‑loop: every process has an owner, a dashboard, and a mechanism to retire or revise it when it no longer serves the intended outcome.

Implementation notes:
• Data contracts: every event used here is defined in §5.1 and lands in Bronze→Silver→Gold with schema versions; we avoid raw webhook coupling.
• Feature flags: we version flags, document blast radius, and wire kill‑switches (Admin → Config) with two‑person approval for money moves.
• Admin operability: before general release of any surface, Support must demonstrate resolution of the top three expected edge cases without engineering.
• Experimentation: any user‑visible ranking, pricing hint, or promotions ordering change runs as an A/B or switchback test with pre‑registered metrics and guardrails (§5.13).

§7.9 — Compensation Bands & Equity Guidelines (Ranges & Principles)

§7.9 — Compensation Bands & Equity Guidelines (Ranges & Principles)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped; city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin tooling and audit trails.

Goals:
• Pay fairly, simply, and predictably; compete for senior builders without distorting the org.
• Use national‑US bands; equity refreshes tied to impact; bonus for on‑call rotations.
• Document the offer process and negotiation principles to avoid hidden bias.

Why this matters:
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1–6. For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax, trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical layer.
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for higher‑risk launches.
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:
• Ranges per level/role; equity mix ranges; founder grants policy; referral bonuses; market review cadence.

Processes & cadences:
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments, city gating decisions.
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday retros; shared ship log.
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter policy, money movement, or public content rules.
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes, code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:
• Offer acceptance rate; regretted attrition; comp‑to‑band variance; diversity goals met at hiring bands.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Ad‑hoc exceptions; over‑index on cash; under‑leveled hires; retention shocks; secrecy around compensation.

Launch checklist (acceptance):
□ Band tables published; equity and bonus policy docs; annual market review; refresh policy; exception log.

Deep dive: Case study — Houston Alpha: How the team used feature flags and admin tools to run a safe Instant Book pilot without code changes mid‑flight.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — ACH returns spike: How Finance and Support coordinate, which macros they use, and how the buyer‑fee discount copy changes temporarily.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — Tax outage during checkout: Allowlist behavior, buyer banner copy, deferred quotes, and daily reconciliation safeguards.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — On‑call handoff: Messaging degradation detected by synthetics; playbook steps; escalation tree; status page language.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.

Deep dive: Scenario — City‑2 gating: What evidence we require to open promotions and tax in the next city, and how we staff support hours in local time.
We document the detection signals, the decision tree, the admin actions available, and the roll‑forward/roll‑back conditions. Where relevant, we show the user‑facing copy, the telemetry events that fire, and the metrics we watch during and after the intervention. Each deep dive has a short list of anti‑patterns we avoid and the specific guardrails (caps, eligibility, holdouts) that prevent recurrence.
