Section 8 — Legal, Policy & Compliance (8.0–8.10)

Generated on 2025-11-04 21:26:38 UTC

Each sub‑section below is a detailed internal blueprint (≥2,500 words) and includes disclaimers.

§8.0 — Overview & Risk Posture (US‑Only Launch)

§8.0 — Overview & Risk Posture (US‑Only Launch)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Define our legal and policy posture for a US‑only launch with city‑by‑city rollout.
• Codify risk appetites and red lines for content, payments, privacy, and safety.
• Make policies actionable with owners, flags, and admin tools.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all users, providers, buyers, and studios operating on the platform within the United States. Covers all public content, bookings, payments, and messaging conducted via the platform or its official communication channels.

Definitions (plain language):
• Artistic nudity: non‑sexualized nudity for artistic purposes; explicit sexual content is prohibited on public surfaces.
• Instant Book: a booking that can be accepted immediately; available only to ID‑verified providers.
• Trusted Pro: an opt‑in background‑checked provider with additional safety signals and minor fee incentives.
• Escrow: funds held by the processor until acceptance of deliverables or completion of studio checkout.
• Safe‑Mode: default media setting for guests and first‑time viewers; suppresses sensitive thumbnails.

Policy Statements:
• US‑only: we contract under US law; we will not knowingly onboard users domiciled outside the US at launch.
• Age limitation: the platform is for adults (18+). No minors may create accounts or appear in content.
• Artistic‑only public surfaces: explicit sexual content is prohibited on public search, profile cards, and feeds.
• Identity diligence: ID verification is required for Instant Book and recommended for all sellers.
• Background checks: optional and consent‑based; adverse‑action steps follow FCRA norms.
• Payments & escrow: use approved processors; no cash off‑platform payments are permitted via our UI.
• Privacy & PII: minimize collected data; mask PII by default; use a vault for sensitive identifiers.
• Accessibility & fairness: commit to WCAG 2.1 AA and to non‑discrimination in access to services.
• Law enforcement: we respond to valid legal process and emergencies with audit trails and privacy guards.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Policy change protocol: draft → legal review → feature flag → city gate → limited launch → measurement → GA.
• Incident triage: classify by severity (user harm, money, privacy); invoke on‑call roles and runbooks.
• Document lifecycle: version external policies; keep internal playbooks aligned and dated with owners.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Tiered enforcement: warnings, temporary limits, removal of content, account holds, or permanent disable.
• Appeals: structured process with timelines; decisions documented; patterns reviewed for fairness.
• Chargebacks & disputes: represent with receipts, chats, manifests, releases; escalate only within policy.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• PII as least‑privilege: mask until unmask reason is given; audit access; limit retention to business needs.
• Evidence retention: keep contracts/releases 7 years; keep booking receipts by finance policy.
• Data localization: US‑region storage only at launch; reviewed before any international expansion.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Policy change notice; adverse‑action templates; DMCA intake form; emergency disclosure checklist; Safe‑Mode rationale; accessibility statement.
• Receipt and SOW templates with plain‑English summaries; background check notices; appeals form.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Safety reports per 1,000 legs; time to first response for safety tickets; dispute win/loss rate; privacy access ledger reviews; accessibility audit completion.
• Quarterly policy review cadence tracked; change log published; on‑call drill pass rate.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Mismatched policy and product behavior → deploy behind flags with clear copy to reduce misreads.
• Over‑collection of data → minimize and vault PII; delete unneeded fields; mask by default.
• Unclear content boundaries → publish visual examples; train moderators; default Safe‑Mode for guests.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ External policy pages reviewed by counsel; admin tools verified; training materials updated; city gates configured; runbooks tested with table‑top exercises.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.1 — Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and Acceptable Use (Key Clauses)

§8.1 — Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and Acceptable Use (Key Clauses)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Publish clear, coherent, and non‑surprising public policies users can read and act on.
• Align the ToS with product realities: escrow, Instant Book, studio deposits, promotions, and Safe‑Mode.
• Ensure Privacy Policy and AUP reflect data minimization and artistic‑only public content.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to every registered and guest user who accesses the site, mobile pages, or official communication channels. The ToS governs contractual relationships; the Privacy Policy explains data practices; the AUP sets behavioral rules.

Definitions (plain language):
• User Content: media and text a user uploads or posts to the platform.
• License: limited license users grant to display, host, and transmit their content for platform features.
• Escrowed Transaction: a booking where funds are held until completion conditions are met.
• Dispute: a disagreement over deliverables, attendance, or rules that invokes support or chargeback processes.

Policy Statements:
• Contract formation: ToS acceptance on signup; changes notified; continued use indicates acceptance.
• Eligibility: 18+, US resident; no minors in content; no use where prohibited by law.
• Fees & payment: buyer service fee, provider fee, taxes, deposits; all itemized; off‑platform payment encouragement prohibited.
• Escrow specifics: timing of charges/holds; release triggers; cancellation and refund math summary; deposits distinct from GMV.
• Licenses: provider retains IP unless a specific SOW says otherwise; platform receives a limited license to host/transform content for features.
• AUP core rules: no explicit sexual content in public; no harassment, hate, doxxing, or illegal activity; respect privacy; no dangerous requests.
• Safety features: Safe‑Mode defaults; reporting tools; IDV; background checks; reputation score logic (transparency without revealing raw signals).
• DMCA/notice‑and‑takedown: agent info; notice requirements; counter‑notice path and timeline.
• Arbitration/class action: optional clause with opt‑out window; small‑claims carve‑out (to be confirmed with counsel).
• Disclaimers: we do not employ providers; we facilitate bookings; we are not liable for off‑platform conduct; limit damages as permitted by law.
• Termination: grounds for account limits/closure; appeal process; data export on closure where feasible.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• ToS update cadence with versioning and redline summaries; banner notices for material changes.
• Privacy data maps kept current; DSR (data subject request) intake with standard verification steps.
• AUP enforcement queue: content moderator workflow integrated with Safe‑Mode and strike system.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Graduated responses: content removal, feature restrictions, temporary holds, permanent disable.
• Recurring abuse: strike thresholds; Trusted Pro badge revocation; promotions ineligibility.
• DMCA compliance: remove on valid notice; restore on counter‑notice unless suit filed; repeat infringer policy.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• What we collect: account, verification, booking, payment tokens, device, and limited log data; no unnecessary sensitive categories.
• How we use data: to provide services, safety, payments, and analytics; no sale of PII; limited sharing with processors and vendors.
• Retention: contracts/releases 7 years; booking and finance records per finance policy; deletion on schedule except legal holds.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• ToS last‑updated banner; privacy data inventory; DMCA agent contact; AUP visual examples sheet; strike system explanation; arbitration opt‑out instructions.
• Email/SMS templates: material change notices; enforcement notices; DMCA responses.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Policy comprehension (help‑center views, time on page); enforcement accuracy (appeal upholds); DMCA SLA; DSR response time; privacy access ledger review rate.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Ambiguous terms → publish examples and FAQs; consult counsel on arbitration options and state carve‑outs.
• Over‑reach in licenses → limit to what is necessary to operate the service; avoid assignment by default.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Counsel review complete; public pages staged; AUP queue live; DMCA agent set; versioning redlines prepared; strike policy connected to reputation signals.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.2 — Content & Safety Policy (Artistic‑Only Public Surfaces, Reporting, Moderation)

§8.2 — Content & Safety Policy (Artistic‑Only Public Surfaces, Reporting, Moderation)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Define what is allowed on public surfaces and how Safe‑Mode works.
• Provide clear reporting, review, and appeal paths that respect creators and protect viewers.
• Prevent harassment, hate, doxxing, and risky off‑platform arrangements.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to profiles, search cards, feeds, messaging previews, and any public‑facing media. Private deliverables may include mature content if lawful and consented, but they are delivered via external links and not hosted by us.

Definitions (plain language):
• Artistic nudity: non‑sexualized displays of the human body used in creative expression or documentary work.
• Explicit sexual content: acts, genitals in sexual context, or fetish material; not permitted on public surfaces.
• Safe‑Mode: default setting that blurs or hides sensitive thumbnails for guests and first‑time viewers; toggle for signed‑in adults.
• Harassment: unwanted conduct that targets a person; includes threats, sexual harassment, doxxing.
• Doxxing: publishing private identifying information without consent.

Policy Statements:
• Public media criteria: allow artistic nudity; disallow explicit sex acts and fetish content on public pages.
• Consent requirements: all persons depicted must be 18+; no minors even in background; creators affirm consent and ownership.
• No harassment or hate: zero tolerance for threats, slurs, or dehumanization; removal and sanctions escalate.
• No illegal content: weapons solicitation, trafficking, drugs, and fraud are prohibited.
• Safe‑Mode defaults: guests and first‑time viewers see blurred sensitive thumbnails; adults can opt in after acknowledgment.
• NSFW label: creators must self‑label sensitive sets; classifiers add secondary checks; moderators resolve disputes.
• Appeals: structured path with second‑level review; examples published to reduce ambiguity.
• Location safety: discourage posting precise home addresses; studio addresses handled via verified studio listings.
• Messaging protections: rate limits, spam detection, PII redaction options (support), and report/ block.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Intake → triage → action flow: content reported triggers a queue; moderators evaluate policy fit; actions applied with templates.
• Escalation: high‑risk items (potential exploitation, credible threats) escalate to T&S lead and legal; involve law enforcement where appropriate.
• Education loop: add clarifying examples to help center when ambiguity recurs; tune classifiers to reduce false positives.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Tiered responses: label, blur, age‑gate, remove; repeat violations escalate to strikes and disable; IB suppression during investigations.
• Harassment outcomes: blocks, message restrictions, and account holds; doxxing treated as severe violation.
• False‑positive safety net: quick appeal channel; restore with apology copy when moderation erred.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• PII minimization in reports and queues; moderator access restricted and audited; redaction tools for public pages.
• Media retention: we store only thumbnails and metadata for moderation; full files remain in external storage controlled by the creator.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Moderator templates: decision rationales; user copies for blur/label/remove; appeal receipts; escalation one‑pagers.
• Safe‑Mode explainer: visual examples; toggle confirmation; guest banner copy.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Safety reports per 1,000 legs; appeal reversal rates; classifier precision/recall; IB suppression counts; time‑to‑action SLAs.
• Harassment recurrence after intervention; user trust scores in post‑moderation surveys.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Over‑ or under‑moderation → calibrate classifiers; publish examples; empower appeals.
• Creator backlash → provide transparent explanations; avoid condescending tone; keep humans in loop for close calls.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Policy page with examples live; Safe‑Mode default verified; moderation queues staffed; classifier thresholds tested; appeal paths documented.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.3 — Background Checks & FCRA Compliance (Notices, Adverse Action)

§8.3 — Background Checks & FCRA Compliance (Notices, Adverse Action)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Offer optional background checks (Trusted Pro) that enhance safety without becoming a barrier to entry.
• Implement FCRA‑compliant flows for consent, notices, disputes, and adverse action.
• Protect privacy and prevent misuse of background data.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to providers who opt into the Trusted Pro program and to buyers where a studio or brand requires checks for on‑premise work. Background checks are not mandatory to browse or book unless specified by a studio’s house rules.

Definitions (plain language):
• Background Check: a consumer report from a screening vendor provided with the provider’s written authorization.
• Pre‑Adverse Action Notice: a notice sent when we might take an action based in whole or part on the report.
• Adverse Action Notice: a final notice if action is taken (e.g., denying Trusted Pro badge).
• Permissible Purpose: the reason we may request a report (safety for marketplace participation).

Policy Statements:
• Consent: explicit, informed, written consent is required; separate from ToS; withdrawable at any time.
• Scope: limited to identity verification, criminal records where lawful, and sex offender registries; no credit checks for creators.
• Use: report is used solely to grant or deny Trusted Pro; not for unrelated decisions; no sharing with other users.
• Adverse action: if considering a negative decision, send pre‑adverse notice with report copy and rights; wait required period before final decision.
• Disputes: if user disputes accuracy, pause action until vendor resolves; document outcomes; re‑evaluate decision.
• Data retention: store minimal artifacts; delete per vendor and legal schedules; restrict admin access with training.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Flow: consent capture → vendor run → results to restricted queue → decision template (approve/consider/insufficient) → notice steps (if consider) → final outcome → badge or denial.
• Training: FCRA basics for Trust admins; scripts for notices; time‑zone aware waiting periods.
• Vendor audits: quarterly SLAs, dispute timelines, and data security attestations.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Outcomes: approve (badge issued), insufficient (ask for resubmission), pre‑adverse + adverse (with required waits), appeal path if new information supplied.
• Misuse: any admin misuse is a severe policy breach; logs reviewed; employment actions may result.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• PII vault for reports; masked views by default; access logs reviewed; retention periods enforced; legal hold overrides documented.
• End‑user privacy: no sharing of report content with other users; we surface only badge/no‑badge and generic safety copy.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: consent form; pre‑adverse notice; adverse action notice; dispute intake; approval email; badge explainer.
• Admin checklists: steps for each outcome; timers for waiting periods; escalation paths.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Completion time; adverse action accuracy; dispute resolution time; badge adoption; appeal success rates; access‑log anomalies.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Jurisdictional variation → vendor handles localization; we allow city gates if requirements differ.
• Over‑reliance on checks → emphasize that reviews and reputation remain primary; do not imply 'guarantee' of safety.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Consent screens tested; vendor contract signed; admin training completed; notice templates reviewed by counsel; badge logic validated in search and fees.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.4 — Contracts & IP (SOW, Model Releases, Licensing Tiers)

§8.4 — Contracts & IP (SOW, Model Releases, Licensing Tiers)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Provide standard templates and a Smart Docs system that aligns expectations and IP rights before the shoot.
• Prevent downstream disputes over usage by capturing license scope and compensation clearly.
• Respect creators’ copyrights while enabling buyers to license what they need.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all paid bookings where deliverables or usage rights are exchanged via the platform. TFP/collaboration bookings may use lightweight agreements but still require model releases where faces are identifiable.

Definitions (plain language):
• Statement of Work (SOW): scope, deliverables, timeline, compensation, change‑order process.
• Model Release: consent by a person depicted to use their likeness under specified terms.
• License: the permission granted by the rights holder to use content in defined ways; may be exclusive or nonexclusive.
• Assignment: transfer of ownership of the IP; rare and requires explicit agreement and additional compensation.

Policy Statements:
• Default posture: the creator (photographer/videographer) owns the copyright; buyers obtain a license selected at checkout.
• License tiers: social/web; advertising; commercial print; broadcast; each with territory/duration options and price add‑ons.
• Model releases: required for identifiable persons; stored with booking; expiration and revocation terms spelled out.
• Change orders: add‑on licenses post‑shoot are supported; receipts amended; SOW updated in Smart Docs.
• Moral rights: where applicable, we avoid derogatory treatment clauses; we permit credit removal if safety requires.
• No hidden assignments: platform license is limited to hosting, processing, and displaying content for the service.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Pre‑shoot: SOW and release e‑sign; deliverables and license selected; both parties see plain‑English summaries.
• Post‑shoot: deliverables manifest posted; acceptance triggers license effectiveness; upgrades handled via change order.
• Disputes: receipts, SOW, and releases become the definitive record; support follows playbook to assess scope.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Breach: failure to deliver or misuse of content triggers remedies (refunds, takedown, license suspension).
• Infringement: DMCA process for third‑party claims; internal investigation where platform features are misused.
• Bad‑faith buyers/providers: sanctions include loss of Trusted Pro, promotions eligibility, or account limits.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• Data retention: SOW/releases stored 7 years; hashes captured for integrity; minimal PII in public artifacts.
• Privacy: releases and SOW not publicly displayed; only status and scope summaries shown to the counterparty.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: SOW per role; model release variants; license matrix; change‑order terms; takedown request forms.
• Help‑center: 'Which license do I need?' wizard; examples of common scenarios.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Dispute rate related to license scope; frequency of change‑order upgrades; time‑to‑sign for SOW/releases; takedown SLAs.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Ambiguous license language → publish examples; require plain‑English summaries; prohibit hidden assignments.
• Edge cases (e.g., collage, AI stylization) → add addenda and clarify derivative works rights.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Templates reviewed by counsel; Smart Docs integrated; license matrix priced; support trained on SOW/release evidence handling.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.5 — Payments, Refunds & Chargebacks (Consumer Law Notes)

§8.5 — Payments, Refunds & Chargebacks (Consumer Law Notes)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Explain money flows plainly and enforce refund/cancellation windows consistently.
• Maximize successful representment in disputes by keeping clean records (escrow, manifests, timestamps).
• Avoid unfair practices; provide accessible help‑center content that sets expectations.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all escrowed transactions, ACH and card payments, deposits, cancellations, and post‑booking adjustments within the US.

Definitions (plain language):
• Escrow: funds held until acceptance; release triggers defined in §1.3 and §4.12.
• Change Order: a mutually agreed price/time adjustment posted to the thread; amends receipts and escrow.
• Chargeback: cardholder disputes a charge with issuer; we respond with evidence.
• ACH Return: bank rejects a debit; we handle via returns codes, fees, and communication.

Policy Statements:
• Clear disclosures: fees, taxes, deposits, and refund windows displayed before purchase and in receipts.
• Refund bands: time‑based buyer refunds; provider‑fault refunds include buyer fee; late cancels tracked for reputation.
• Chargeback playbook: gather SOW, releases, chats, acceptance, manifest; construct a concise narrative; file within deadline.
• ACH handling: post returns code; adjust buyer fee if method changes; reattempt under policy.
• No cash: off‑platform payments are prohibited within the UI; repeated attempts can throttle messaging.
• Tips: zero platform fee; optional and processed post‑completion.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Support macros: standard refunds; reschedule; partial refunds; provider‑fault; chargeback kits.
• Admin tools: re‑issue receipts; partial refund apportionment; deposit auth/capture logs for studios.
• Finance close: daily reconciliation; settlement variance alarms; tax export by jurisdiction.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Outcomes: refund issued, denied (with rationale), partial; chargeback won/lost; ACH return resolved.
• Abuse controls: refund/chargeback abuse flags; repeat offenders lose Instant Book or are limited.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• Sensitive data: card/ACH tokens only; we never store PANs; PII vaulted and masked; least‑privilege on admin pages.
• Retention: receipts kept per finance policy; chargeback evidence retained for at least 18 months.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: refund confirmations; chargeback narratives; ACH return explanations; late‑cancel warnings.
• Help‑center: 'How refunds work,' 'What happens in a dispute,' 'Deposits for studios,' 'Tips & payouts'.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Refund SLA; representment win rate; settlement variance; ACH return rate; average time to resolution; user satisfaction scores for money tickets.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Ambiguous refund copy → standardize; preview math in price box; reduce surprises.
• Evidence gaps → require manifest and acceptance; reduce 'not as described' disputes with SOW clarity.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Macros published; finance reports green 14/14 days; chargeback kit quality audits ≥ 95%; dispute loss rate trending down.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.6 — Sales‑Tax & Marketplace Facilitator Stance (State Matrix; Tax Engine)

§8.6 — Sales‑Tax & Marketplace Facilitator Stance (State Matrix; Tax Engine)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Rely on a tax engine for jurisdiction determination and rate calculation; avoid hard‑coding volatile rules.
• Document when we act as collector vs when the provider does, based on service type and state posture.
• Ensure receipts and exports itemize tax correctly; support amendments and refunds.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to taxable services and fees in the United States where state or local law imposes sales or similar transaction taxes. At launch we rely on a tax engine configured for US‑only; coverage expands city‑by‑city per §6.3.

Definitions (plain language):
• Marketplace facilitator: a platform obligated in some jurisdictions to collect/ remit tax on third‑party sales.
• Taxable base: the portion of the transaction subject to tax (service, fees, deposits if captured).
• Sourcing: origin‑based vs destination‑based rules for services; determined by the engine using addresses.

Policy Statements:
• Engine‑first policy: we use tax provider quotes at checkout and store a tax transaction id; we do not invent rates.
• Role mapping: talent services vs studio rentals may be taxed differently; we configure item categories accordingly.
• Receipts: show tax lines by leg; deposit auth not taxed; captured deposits taxed if jurisdiction requires.
• Refunds & amendments: credit memos issued through the engine; partial refunds adjust tax proportionally.
• Allowlist rollout: only enable tax in states we have configured and tested; show banner where tax is not yet collected.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Admin tax map: city/state allowlist; category mapping; override flags when the engine is down.
• Nightly reconciliation: totals by jurisdiction; exception report for missing tax ids; SLA checks for latency.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Outcomes: tax collected & remitted via engine; tax not applicable; or pending due to outage (with user banner).
• Mis‑classification: fix mapping; issue adjustments; document in reconciliation logs.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• PII minimization: addresses and TINs stored in vault; tax data limited to what is required; logs scrubbed.
• Retention: export archives per finance schedule; legal holds paused when necessary.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: tax‑enabled banner copy; 'tax not collected yet in your state' banner; reconciliation playbook; outage copy.
• Help‑center: 'How taxes work,' 'Why was tax charged?,' 'Which services are taxed?'

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Tax latency; quote success rate; reconciliation variance; number of overrides; user contacts about tax confusion.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Volatile rules → centralize in engine; avoid bespoke logic in app; maintain a small allowlist for coverage.
• User confusion → show simple copy and itemized receipts; link to help center; keep support macros ready.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Engine configured; allowlist published; receipts itemize correctly; nightly reconciliation and exports passing for 30 days.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.7 — Data Protection & PII (Public‑Facing Summary of §5.7)

§8.7 — Data Protection & PII (Public‑Facing Summary of §5.7)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Explain plainly what data we collect, why, and how we protect it.
• Honor least‑privilege access, masking, and audit trails for PII.
• Offer user controls (exports, deletion where applicable) and clear contact channels.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all personal data processed in connection with accounts, bookings, messaging, payments, and safety operations within the United States.

Definitions (plain language):
• PII: information that identifies a person (e.g., name, email, phone) and sensitive identifiers (DOB, TIN).
• Vault: secure store for sensitive fields; access restricted and audited.
• Data Subject Request (DSR): a user request for access, correction, or deletion of their data where applicable.

Policy Statements:
• Data minimization: collect only what we need to operate and secure the service (identity, payments, safety).
• Purpose limitation: do not repurpose data for unrelated advertising; usage limited to service operations and safety.
• Security: encryption in transit and at rest; tokenized payments; masked PII in admin; JIT elevation for sensitive unmasking.
• User controls: profile edits; download receipts; data export on request; account closure flow with data retention explanation.
• Third parties: share data only with processors and vendors necessary to deliver the service; contracts require security and privacy safeguards.
• Children: 18+ only; remove accounts if discovered to be underage; report where required.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• DSR flow: intake → verify identity → scope data → fulfill → log; denial templates for narrow exceptions.
• Breach response: incident roles; containment; notification thresholds; post‑mortem with remediation tasks.
• Access reviews: quarterly RBAC review; remove stale admin accounts; rotate secrets on schedule.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Enforcement: violations of access policy trigger investigation; repeated misuse leads to employment action; all actions audited.
• Appeals: users can escalate DSR outcomes via support; internal privacy officer reviews edge cases.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• Retention schedule: finance records, releases, and SOW timelines; purge jobs for expired artifacts; legal hold overrides documented.
• Transparency: publish privacy summary with last‑updated date; log of material changes.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: DSR intake; identity verification steps; breach notice skeleton; privacy summary page; vendor due‑diligence checklist.
• Training decks: PII handling and phishing drills; admin console privacy controls primer.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• DSR SLA; time to revoke stale admin access; secrets rotation adherence; privacy incident count; audit of PII access logs.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Over‑collection → reduce fields and retention; Vault misuse → increase audits and training; vendor risk → conduct due diligence and monitoring.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Privacy summary published; DSR tooling live; access review calendar set; breach runbook tested; vendor checklist adopted.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
