§8.8 — Subpoena & Law‑Enforcement Process (With §4.14.15 Hooks)

§8.8 — Subpoena & Law‑Enforcement Process (With §4.14.15 Hooks)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Respond lawfully and narrowly to valid legal process while protecting user privacy and safety.
• Provide an emergency disclosure path for imminent harm consistent with law.
• Maintain impeccable audit trails and chain‑of‑custody for any data disclosed.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all requests from government entities, private litigants, and law enforcement seeking user data.

Definitions (plain language):
• Legal Process: a subpoena, court order, or warrant that compels disclosure of certain records.
• Emergency Disclosure: a request asserting imminent harm to a person; processed under a defined policy.
• Notice: where permitted by law, informing users that their data has been requested.

Policy Statements:
• Intake: verify authority, scope, and jurisdiction; reject over‑broad or improper requests; require correct service.
• Notice: unless legally barred, inform the user with a copy of the request and time to object.
• Narrow tailoring: produce only what is specified; prefer metadata over content where lawful.
• Chain of custody: hash and inventory produced files; store in restricted evidence repository.
• Emergency requests: accept via official channels; require written confirmation; log and review post‑hoc.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Admin integration: §4.14.15 legal holds; evidence tagging; restricted access groups.
• Escalation: counsel reviews; senior approval for content disclosures; regular audits of requests.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Enforcement: deny improper requests; seek to quash where appropriate; document refusals and reasons.
• Abuse reporting: if a request appears abusive, escalate; do not comply until clarified.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• PII minimization in productions; redact third‑party PII where not requested; secure transfer methods; retention per legal hold schedule.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: subpoena intake form; user notice; emergency disclosure form; production cover letter; denial letter.
• Logs: request register with dates, types, outcomes; annual transparency report summary.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Request volume; mean time to legal review; % of requests narrowed; transparency report cadence.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Improper service → train intake; scope creep → insist on narrow requests; confidentiality orders → track notice restrictions and expiry.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Counsel on retainer; intake mailbox monitored; evidence repository configured; transparency report template ready.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.

§8.9 — Accessibility & Anti‑Discrimination Commitments

§8.9 — Accessibility & Anti‑Discrimination Commitments

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Deliver equitable access to the platform and prohibit discrimination by users in listings and bookings.
• Commit to WCAG 2.1 AA and continuous accessibility improvement.
• Protect users from harassment and discriminatory conduct in content and messages.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to all product surfaces, content, and user interactions. Providers and buyers must comply with non‑discrimination rules in their offers and conduct.

Definitions (plain language):
• Accessibility: making content usable by people with disabilities, including visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive.
• Discrimination: unfavorable treatment based on protected classes (e.g., race, gender, disability, religion, sexual orientation).
• Accommodation: reasonable modifications to policies and practices where appropriate.

Policy Statements:
• WCAG commitment: design system patterns aim for 2.1 AA; audits scheduled; defects tracked like product bugs.
• Non‑discrimination: providers may define genre/skill/availability criteria but may not refuse work based on protected classes.
• Harassment policy: aligned with §8.2; zero tolerance for slurs, targeting, or exclusionary conduct.
• Accommodation: support channels for accessibility needs; studio house rules must include accessible entry info where applicable.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Accessibility QA: keyboard nav tests, contrast checks, screen reader flows; bug triage and regression tests.
• Enforcement: report intake for discrimination; evidence review; proportionate actions; education first where misunderstanding is likely.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Outcomes: warning, content removal, booking cancellation support, or account limits; repeat violations escalate.
• Appeals: allow users to contest decisions; moderators consider context and cultural sensitivity.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• Data: avoid collecting protected class data unless required for law; do not use protected attributes in ranking or promotions.
• Privacy: accommodation requests handled discreetly; limited visibility; retention minimal.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Templates: accessibility statement; discrimination policy; report forms; accommodation request flows; guidance for studio accessibility disclosure.
• Training: inclusive language for support; accessible design patterns for product and marketing.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Accessibility defect rate; time to fix high‑severity accessibility bugs; discrimination report outcomes; user satisfaction among screen‑reader users.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Token compliance without usability → test with real users; uneven enforcement → publish examples and decisions to reduce ambiguity.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Statement published; audits scheduled; design system updated; training completed; report flows live.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

§8.10 — Compliance Calendar (Filings, Policy Reviews, Audits)

§8.10 — Compliance Calendar (Filings, Policy Reviews, Audits)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped.
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests.
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible, auditable launches.
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:
• Create a predictable cadence for legal and compliance tasks so nothing is reactive.
• Bundle policy reviews with product milestones; keep public pages fresh and versioned.
• Audit vendors and internal controls on a regular schedule.

Scope & Applicability:
Applies to Trust & Safety, Finance, Legal, and Data teams; coordinated by an owner who maintains the shared calendar.

Definitions (plain language):
• Quarterly: policy reviews, RBAC access review, vendor SLAs and security attestations, data retention jobs audit.
• Monthly: finance close QA, tax reconciliation, promotions invalid‑click review, privacy access ledger report.
• Annual: SOC evidence pack progress, pentest, DMCA agent check, ADA/accessibility review, disaster recovery drill.

Policy Statements:
• Owners: named DRI for each recurring task; backups assigned; escalations defined.
• Artifacts: checklists stored in admin; timestamps captured; outcomes posted to an internal 'compliance log'.
• City‑by‑city: calendar reflects city launches; tasks added as tax, promotions, and studios enable in new cities.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:
• Enforcement: missed tasks trigger escalation; repeat misses lead to process changes; calendar visible to execs.
• Risk‑based prioritization: high‑risk tasks take precedence during incident weeks; low‑risk items may defer with approval.

Enforcement & Remedies:
• Data hygiene: purge jobs verified; evidence repositories trimmed; legal holds reviewed and released when resolved.
• Privacy: DSR volume monitored; training refreshers scheduled; secrets rotation logged.

Data, Privacy & Retention:
• Templates: quarterly review checklist; RBAC access review form; vendor questionnaire; DR drill script; SOC evidence index.
• Dashboards: compliance status board; upcoming deadlines; error budgets for misses.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):
• Task completion rate; on‑time rate; audit findings; vendor remediation rates; incident reduction post‑reviews.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:
• Calendar sprawl → consolidate and assign DRIs; drift between policy and product → tie reviews to release trains.
• Vendor fatigue → rotate deep‑dives; keep a minimal baseline questionnaire for low‑risk vendors.

Risks & Mitigations:
• Calendar published; owners and backups named; first cycle completed with notes; dashboard showing green/yellow/red for each area.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):
□ Counsel review completed; public pages staged with versioning.
□ Admin tools wired (queues, redaction, approvals) with audit trails.
□ Training delivered to Support/T&S/Finance; templates published.
□ Feature flags and city allowlists configured; rollback tested.
□ Telemetry and dashboards live; acceptance tests passed.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake, escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license, and moral rights.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Consider' background result: pre‑adverse and adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat infringer policy.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and reconciliation.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Emergency disclosure request: verification, least disclosure, audit trail.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Accessibility complaint: reproductions, remediation, and communication cadence.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate enforcement and appeal paths.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario — 'Services not rendered' chargeback: assembling evidence and narrative.
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Implementation Notes:
• Feature Flags & City Gates: externally visible policy toggles ship behind flags; Admin can rollback with a two‑step confirmation; events are audited.
• Admin Operability: every rule has a corresponding tool in Admin (approve/deny/redact/pause/escalate) with immutable logs.
• Evidence Hygiene: store hashes and immutable links; redact PII in views; never edit originals; legal holds override deletion where applicable.
• Copy Clarity: explain outcomes and next steps; avoid citing laws in emails; link to help‑center with examples.
• Training: quarterly refreshers for T&S, Support, Finance; FCRA basics; chargeback representment; accessibility etiquette.
• Measurement: we track leading/lagging indicators to tune thresholds and staffing.

Section 9 — Financial Model & Unit Economics (9.0–9.8)

Generated on 2025-11-04 22:41:06 UTC

Each sub‑section is a detailed write‑up (≥2,500 words) with formulas and acceptance checklists aligned to Sections 1–8.

§9.0 — Modeling Assumptions (Traffic, Conversion, City Ramp)

§9.0 — Modeling Assumptions (Traffic, Conversion, City Ramp)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Establish realistic, testable assumptions for traffic, conversion, and growth that tie to product flags and city gates.
• Align finance with measurement: every assumption maps to an event or metric in §5.
• Create a baseline and two alt scenarios (conservative/aggressive) without overfitting early noise.

Key variables & baselines:
• Cities & cohorts: Houston (Cohort‑1) GA at T+90; City‑2 pilot at T+180; City‑3 at T+240 under §6.4 readiness.
• Supply (providers): Active providers = listed + ID‑verified with ≥1 package; Trusted Pro as a subset.
• Demand (buyers): Active buyers = ≥1 inquiry or booking in trailing 28 days.
• Conversion: Search→Inquiry (S→I) and Inquiry→Booking (I→B) defined in §6; rep score & Instant Book shift these.
• GMV: Gross value of bookings excluding buyer fee and tax; sum of subtotals per leg.
• AOV: Average order value per leg; varies by role and city tier.
• Cancellations: Time‑banded rates; late cancels affect reputation and rebooking behavior.
• Chargebacks: Rate on card transactions; ACH has different failure profile (returns).
• Payment mix: Card vs ACH share; ACH reduces buyer fee but lowers processing cost.
• Promotions adoption: Share of eligible providers purchasing CPC/Featured; ROAS targets from §3.3.
• Tax coverage: Allowlist states per §4.12/§6.3; banner when off.
• Seasonality: Minor seasonality; spikes near holidays and local event seasons.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• ActiveProviders_t = NewProviders_t + Reactivated_t − Churn_t
• ActiveBuyers_t = NewBuyers_t + Reactivated_t − Churn_t
• Inquiries_t = Searches_t × (S→I) × EligibilityRate_t
• Bookings_t = Inquiries_t × (I→B) × (1 − CancelRate_t)
• GMV_t = Σ (BookingSubtotal_i) for all completed legs in period t
• AOV_role,city = GMV_role,city / Bookings_role,city
• TakeRate_net ≈ (ProviderFee% × GMV) + BuyerFee% × GMV_equiv + PromotionsRevenue − ProcessorCOGS − VariableOpsCOGS

Cohort maturation curves:
Supply tends to mature faster than demand in creator marketplaces. We model a s‑curve for provider activation (profile→IDV→first package→first booking) and a slightly slower curve for buyer repeat rate. These curves are parameterized so we can fit them once we have 8–12 weeks of telemetry.

Eligibility & gating:
Availability, distance, price fit, and NSFW toggle are filters that reduce the eligible supply set a buyer sees. Promotions never expand eligibility; they only surface within matching results.

Data discipline:
Every assumption above maps to a field or table in the §5 warehouse (fact_search, fact_inquiry, fact_booking_leg, fact_payment, fact_promo). Finance does not hard‑code rates; we consume aggregates from Gold tables with freshness SLOs.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Search→Inquiry and Inquiry→Booking (city×role) with 7/14/28d trends
• Active providers and buyers (28d) with growth and churn by cohort
• GMV, AOV, and leg count by city×role
• Cancellation and chargeback rates by payment type
• ACH share of checkouts; promotions adoption and ROAS by role×city

Top risks & mitigations:
• Early noise overfitting → use ranges and guardrails; wait for stable cohorts before revising baselines.
• Mis‑measured eligibility → implement precise denominator definitions and audits in §5.8.
• Seasonality misreads → annotate events (festivals, holidays) in a calendar dimension.

Acceptance checklist:
□ Assumptions document reviewed monthly; deltas tied to observed telemetry.
□ Cohort curves parameterized and ready to fit after 8–12 weeks of data.
□ Gold tables for search, inquiry, booking, and payment pass DQ gates.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.1 — Revenue Drivers (Take‑Rate, Promotions, Other)

§9.1 — Revenue Drivers (Take‑Rate, Promotions, Other)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Define all revenue streams with formulas that tie to product behavior and receipts.
• Make revenue recognition auditable via booking legs, receipts, and promotions wallet.
• Avoid vanity revenue—focus on durable drivers aligned with user value.

Key variables & baselines:
• Provider fee: 12% of booking subtotal; drops to 10% on portion > $1,000; −1% Instant Book; −0.5% Trusted Pro (floor 9%).
• Buyer fee: 5% (min $3); 3% with ACH where enabled; refunded on provider‑fault cancels.
• Promotions: Search Boost (CPC) and Featured (weekly flat) usage‑based with eligibility; clear caps and labels.
• Tips: 0% platform fee; processed post‑completion (not revenue).
• Other: None at launch (no subscriptions); potential future add‑ons deferred to §13.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• Revenue_provider_fees_t = Σ (ProviderFeeRate_i × Subtotal_i) over completed legs i
• Revenue_buyer_fees_t = Σ (BuyerFeeRate_i × Subtotal_i) adjusted for refunds and ACH discount
• Revenue_promotions_t = CPC_clicks_t × CPC_price_t + Featured_slots_t × Weekly_price_t
• NetRevenue_t = Revenue_provider_fees_t + Revenue_buyer_fees_t + Revenue_promotions_t − ProcessorCOGS_t − Credits_invalid_clicks_t

Why buyer fee exists:
Buyer fee offsets processor costs and support while keeping provider take‑home attractive. The ACH discount aligns incentives by reducing both processor cost and buyer fee, encouraging low‑cost rails.

Promotions alignment:
Promotions generate revenue only when providers opt in, and only within relevance caps. Holdouts quantify incremental GMV so providers spend when it pays, not because ranking is rigged.

Recognition timing:
Provider and buyer fees are recognized when the leg completes or is accepted; promotions revenue is recognized as clicks/impressions deliver; credits for invalid clicks reduce promotions revenue as contra‑revenue.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Take‑rate components: provider vs buyer vs promotions (stacked) by city×role
• Promotions adoption, CPC, CTR, ROAS distribution; invalid‑click credit rate
• ACH share and its effect on buyer fee and processor COGS
• Refunded buyer fees due to provider‑fault cancels

Top risks & mitigations:
• Perception of pay‑to‑win → capped slots, labels, eligibility gates; transparency in 'Why am I seeing this?'
• Buyer fee backlash → clear value copy (escrow, contracts, support) and ACH discount messaging
• Revenue leakage via off‑platform payments → in‑chat warnings, throttles, Trusted Pro incentives

Acceptance checklist:
□ Revenue lines reconcile to receipts (per leg) and promotions wallet events.
□ Invalid‑click credits pipeline operational; audits sampled weekly.
□ ACH effect on buyer fee and processing cost visible in dashboards.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:

• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.2 — COGS (Processing, Trust/Safety, Tax, Deliverables, Comms)

§9.2 — COGS (Processing, Trust/Safety, Tax, Deliverables, Comms)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Identify all variable costs tied directly to transactions and exposure.
• Model processor fees for card vs ACH correctly; capture per‑event costs (IDV, BG, tax, comms, safety).
• Keep COGS low without compromising safety or compliance.

Key variables & baselines:
• Card processing: Assume ~2.9% + $0.30 per card charge (authorization and capture as applicable); 3DS where required.
• ACH processing: Assume ~0.5–0.8% effective with caps; returns handling cost per event.
• ID verification: Per‑check cost; subsidized for early cohorts; later user‑paid or bundled in Trusted Pro pricing.
• Background checks: Pass‑through or partially subsidized; include adverse‑action processing overhead.
• Tax engine: Per transaction quote + monthly minimum; refunds/amendments charged per credit memo.
• Content safety: Classifier scans per media; human moderation minutes for escalations.
• E‑signature: Per envelope for SOW/releases; negotiated tiers.
• SMS/email: Per SMS/segment and email send; deliverability monitoring.
• Chargeback fees: Per dispute fee; lost cases incur processor fees; representment labor cost.
• Invalid‑click credits: Reducing promotions revenue; monitoring and auto‑credit pipeline cost.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• ProcessorCOGS_t = Σ (CardCharges_j × (rate% × amount_j + $0.30)) + Σ (ACHDebits_k × (ach_rate% × amount_k))
• TrustSafetyCOGS_t = IDV_checks × IDV_unit_cost + BG_checks × BG_unit_cost + Moderation_minutes × cost_per_min
• TaxCOGS_t = TaxQuotes × quote_cost + CreditMemos × memo_cost
• CommsCOGS_t = SMS_segments × sms_cost + Emails × email_cost
• ChargebackCOGS_t = Disputes × dispute_fee + Losses × lost_rev_effect

External deliverables keep hosting COGS low:
By using external storage for heavy media, we avoid large variable storage and egress costs. We still incur classifier and moderation costs on thumbnails and metadata.

Unit cost levers:
Negotiating ACH pricing, batching signatures into envelopes, and training classifiers to reduce human moderation minutes are key levers on COGS.

Attribution discipline:
COGS must reconcile with usage events in §5; finance uses event counts × unit costs and cross‑checks with vendor invoices and Admin exports.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• COGS % of GMV and % of revenue; processor cost per $ collected (card vs ACH)
• Moderation minutes per 1,000 media items; IDV/BG adoption vs subsidy spend
• Tax engine latency and success rate; credit memo accuracy; chargeback win rate

Top risks & mitigations:
• Processor fee creep → monitor effective rate; negotiate with volume; shift mix to ACH where eligible
• Under‑resourced moderation → safety risk; over‑moderation → creator churn; balance with training and examples
• Tax misconfiguration → reconciliation variance; keep allowlist tight and audited

Acceptance checklist:
□ COGS model wired to vendor usage; reconciliation report green for 30 days.
□ ACH return macros and fee handling tested; chargeback kit process audited.
□ Content safety staffing plan in place for peak loads.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.3 — Opex & Headcount Plan (by Phase)

§9.3 — Opex & Headcount Plan (by Phase)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Plan operating expense and headcount that unlock milestones without over‑hiring.
• Tie hiring to GA gates and city expansion; prefer contractors for commodity tasks early.
• Keep data/infra spend disciplined (≤15% of GMV).

Key variables & baselines:
• People: Engineering, Product, Design, Data, SRE, Support, Trust, Finance, City Ops, Marketing.
• Vendors: Comms, e‑signature, background/IDV, tax, analytics, observability, ticketing.
• Facilities: Remote‑first; optional coworking; travel for city ops and studio partners.
• Tooling: Source control, CI/CD, security scans, feature flags, experimentation, admin console.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• Payroll_t = Σ (FTE_role × fully_loaded_cost_role) + Contractors_t
• VendorOpex_t = Σ (SaaS_subscriptions) + Minimums (tax, comms) not in COGS
• TotalOpex_t = Payroll_t + VendorOpex_t + Facilities_t + Misc_t

Phase‑linked hiring:
We add squads as §6 milestones unlock: Beta adds Growth/Promotions; GA adds Money/Tax and Studios; post‑GA adds SRE. Support and T&S ramp with ticket volume.

Contractor vs FTE:
Use contractors for non‑differentiated tasks (e.g., help‑center population, manual reviews) while retaining core differentiation (search, booking, money, admin) in‑house.

Cost discipline:
Finance reviews TB/day (data) and compute envelopes (§5.12). Feature owners are accountable for admin operability to prevent support burden.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Opex runway in months; burn multiple; payroll % of total opex; vendor spend vs plan
• Ticket volume per 1,000 legs; staffing vs SLA; error budget burn vs engineer operating time

Top risks & mitigations:
• Hiring ahead of demand → burn increases without revenue; mitigate with gates
• Under‑investing in SRE → reliability risk; mitigate with phased on‑call and drills
• Vendor sprawl → consolidate; maintain an approved vendor list and renewal calendar

Acceptance checklist:
□ Headcount plan per phase approved; offer templates ready; recruiting funnel metrics live.
□ Vendor roster with costs and owners published; renewal dates in calendar.
□ Runway and burn tracked monthly; alerts when thresholds breached.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.

• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.4 — Marketing & CAC (City Seeding vs National)

§9.4 — Marketing & CAC (City Seeding vs National)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Establish a city‑first marketing plan with measurable CAC and payback windows.
• Use incentives (verification subsidies, Boost coupons) instead of subscriptions to drive quality supply.
• Balance organic loops (boards, posts, referrals) with targeted paid tests.

Key variables & baselines:
• Channels: Creator referrals, studio partners, social ads (limited tests), content marketing, PR, email sequences, RFP broadcasts.
• Incentives: IDV subsidies for early providers; Trusted Pro coupon; buyer fee holidays for first booking in new city.
• Budget framing: CAC caps relative to LTV; city‑level spend with clear stop/go criteria.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• CAC_channel = Spend_channel / NewActiveBuyers_or_Providers_from_channel
• Payback_months = CAC / MonthlyContributionMargin_per_user
• LTV_user = Σ (ContributionMargin_t × Retention_t) over horizon H

City‑first tactics:
Leverage local studios, meetups, and micro‑influencers. Feature local creators in home carousels. Offer limited buyer‑fee holidays (time‑boxed) to spur first bookings.

Quality over volume:
We avoid paying for low‑intent traffic. We favor channels that yield ID‑verified providers and ready‑to‑book buyers.

Attribution:
UTM discipline, post‑signup surveys, and blended CAC reporting prevent false confidence in any one channel.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• CAC by channel; blended CAC; first‑booking rate; time to first booking; repeat rate at 60/90 days
• IDV adoption; Trusted Pro share; promotions usage among active providers

Top risks & mitigations:
• Vanity signups → require package publishing and first inquiry to count as activation
• Over‑spend on paid social → cap tests; demand ≥2× contribution payback within 9–12 months
• Referral fraud → limit per‑account rewards; require verified activity

Acceptance checklist:
□ City marketing brief approved; budget caps and stop‑rules configured.
□ Referral tracking live; coupon issuance and abuse guards in admin.
□ Attribution dashboards validated with holdout cells where feasible.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.5 — 24‑Month P&L Scenarios (Base / Conservative / Aggressive)

§9.5 — 24‑Month P&L Scenarios (Base / Conservative / Aggressive)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Provide a 24‑month P&L structure with three scenarios tied to city launches and product milestones.
• Make it easy to update with real telemetry and to communicate to stakeholders.
• Ensure cash planning reflects realistic opex and COGS envelopes.

Key variables & baselines:
• Horizon: 24 months from launch; quarterly checkpoints for board updates.
• Scenarios: Conservative (slower adoption), Base (plan), Aggressive (faster promos ROI and ACH uptake).
• City timing: Houston GA by ~Month 6; City‑2 Month 9; City‑3 Month 12 (if §6.4 gates pass).

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• Revenue_t = ProviderFees_t + BuyerFees_t + Promotions_t
• COGS_t = Processor_t + TrustSafety_t + TaxEngine_t + Comms_t + Chargeback_t
• GrossMargin_t = Revenue_t − COGS_t
• Opex_t = Payroll_t + VendorOpex_t + Facilities_t + Misc_t
• EBITDA_t = GrossMargin_t − Opex_t
• Cash_t = Cash_{t−1} + EBITDA_t − Capex_t

Scenario deltas:
The aggressive case assumes higher ACH adoption (→ lower processing cost but slightly lower buyer fee), higher promotions adoption with sustainable ROAS, and faster IDV/Trusted Pro uptake improving conversion.

Communication:
We present scenarios as ranges with narrative drivers rather than single‑point forecasts. Board updates highlight which drivers moved and why.

Updating cadence:
Monthly actuals roll into the model; quarterly we re‑baseline scenario envelopes to maintain credibility.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• GMV growth by city; take‑rate mix; promotions revenue share; processor cost as % of collections
• Gross margin %; opex ratio; EBITDA trajectory; runway months at current burn

Top risks & mitigations:
• Optimism bias → keep conservative case plausible and funded; treat aggressive as upside-only
• Uncontrolled opex → hiring frozen until milestones; vendor renewals scrutinized
• City launch slips → build schedule slack; emphasize quality signals before spend

Acceptance checklist:
□ Scenario workbook built with inputs linked to §5 Gold tables.
□ Quarterly board pack template prepared with red/yellow/green on key drivers.
□ Runway calculator validated with cash reconciliation.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.6 — Sensitivity Analysis (Fees, ACH, Promotions, Studios, Cancellations)

§9.6 — Sensitivity Analysis (Fees, ACH, Promotions, Studios, Cancellations)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Quantify how small changes in key inputs move contribution margin and runway.
• Prioritize levers that we can influence (ACH adoption, promotions ROAS, cancellation policy).
• Expose hidden convexities (e.g., chargebacks) early.

Key variables & baselines:
• Levers: Provider fee floors; buyer fee ACH discount; promotions adoption and CPC floors; studio attach; cancellation policy bands.
• Friction terms: Chargeback rates; dispute win rate; tax engine latency; moderation load; ACH returns.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• ΔContribution = ∂(Revenue − COGS)/∂x × Δx, evaluated at Base scenario
• Elasticity_ROAS = ∂GMV_incremental/∂CPC / CPC
• ACH_effect = (ΔBuyerFee − ΔProcessorCost) at Δ(ACH share)

ACH lever:
Higher ACH share reduces processor cost and buyer fee revenue; net effect often positive due to cost savings and buyer conversion lift.

Promotions lever:
Promotions revenue matters only if ROAS≥2.5× and invalid‑click credits are low; we control CPC floors and density caps city‑by‑city.

Cancellation policy:
Tighter late‑cancel penalties reduce waste but may reduce demand; measure rebooking offsets and reputation effects.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Tornado chart of contribution drivers; ACH net effect; promotions incremental GMV; cancellation impact on net revenue
• Studio attach rate and deposit claim rates; effect on GMV and support costs

Top risks & mitigations:
• Over‑tuning to early data → require confidence intervals; avoid noisy toggling
• Hidden correlations → run multifactor analyses; keep experiments orthogonal where possible

Acceptance checklist:
□ Sensitivity dashboard live; drivers ranked by impact and controllability.
□ Levers with high impact assigned owners and experiments.
□ Guardrails set for fee and CPC floor changes per city.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.7 — Cash Runway & Milestones (Targets to Unlock Next Raises)

§9.7 — Cash Runway & Milestones (Targets to Unlock Next Raises)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Ensure 18–24 months of runway with conservative burn; tie hiring and marketing unlocks to concrete milestones.
• Define the metrics that unlock seed extension or Series A.
• Provide a clear 'stop‑spend' protocol if KPIs regress.

Key variables & baselines:
• Starting cash: Seed proceeds net of fees; maintain minimum cash covenant target.
• Milestones: Beta KPIs (§6.2), GA KPIs (§6.3), City‑3 scale (§6.4), promotions ROAS, tax coverage states.
• Buffers: 3‑month buffer for city slips; vendor prepayments under review.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• Runway_months = Cash / MonthlyBurn (rolling 3‑month average)
• HiringUnlock = 1 if (GMV growth & conversion KPIs ≥ thresholds) else 0
• MarketingUnlock = 1 if (CAC_payback ≤ 12 months & ROAS ≥ target) else 0

Unlock criteria:
We hire ahead only when revenue and trust metrics are sustainably on track. Promotions GA scales when ROAS holds with caps.

Stop‑spend protocol:
If two consecutive months miss red‑line KPIs, we pause hiring, reduce paid marketing, and focus on conversion and trust fixes.

Investor narrative:
We present a measured plan: city‑by‑city wins, strong NPS among creators, and usage‑based monetization with fairness guardrails.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Runway months; burn multiple; EBITDA trend; CAC payback; ROAS; GMV per active buyer/provider; NPS
• Trust/share: IDV %, Trusted Pro %, safety reports per 1k legs; payout latency; chargeback loss rate

Top risks & mitigations:
• Over‑optimistic hiring → tie to unlock rules; publish 'freeze' triggers
• Unexpected processor fee hikes → multi‑processor readiness; ACH mix push

Acceptance checklist:
□ Runway calculator live; unlock/ freeze rules documented; comms plan for spend changes.
□ Board dashboard includes red/yellow/green gates on milestones.
□ Cash reconciliation to bank statements completed monthly.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.8 — KPI Dashboard for Board Updates (Definitions & Sources)

§9.8 — KPI Dashboard for Board Updates (Definitions & Sources)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative; replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free; monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only; deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:
• Define the board‑level KPIs, their exact formulas, and their data sources so updates are consistent.
• Ensure every KPI is explainable and tied to controllable levers.
• Standardize red/yellow/green thresholds with owners.

Key variables & baselines:
• KPI families: Liquidity (S→I, I→B), Growth (active buyers/providers), Economics (GMV, take‑rate, margin), Trust (IDV %, safety), Payments (ACH share, payout latency), Promotions (adoption, ROAS), Support (FRT, FRR).
• Sources: Gold tables from §5.5; event schemas from §5.1; freshness SLOs from §5.12; admin actions from §4.14.*.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):
• S→I = Inquiries / Searches (eligible)
• I→B = Bookings / Inquiries (eligible)
• GMV = Σ booking subtotals (completed legs)
• Take‑rate = (ProviderFee + BuyerFee + Promotions − ProcessorCOGS) / GMV
• ROAS (promotions) = Incremental GMV × TakeRate / PromotionsSpend
• CAC_blended = TotalMarketingSpend / NewActiveBuyers (or providers)

Explainability:
We show source events, denominators, and example calculations. For ROAS, we use holdout incrementality—not naive last‑touch attribution.

Thresholds:
Red/yellow/green bands are set from §6 targets. Thresholds are reviewed quarterly and ratcheted only after sustained performance.

Presentation:
Board deck uses consistent tiles with spark lines, YoY/period deltas, and short 'what moved' memos per owner.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• KPI tile freshness (hours since last update); error budget burn; number of data quality exceptions
• Owner list with backups; on‑call data steward for board week

Top risks & mitigations:
• Metric drift → lock definitions with a ledger; require changelog and approver for edits
• Gaming → monitor for anomalies; tie incentives to a basket of KPIs, not a single metric

Acceptance checklist:
□ Dashboard ready by T‑5 business days before board; freeze window enforced.
□ Single‑page appendix lists formulas and sources; DQ report attached.
□ Owners sign off on their tiles with short narratives.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
• Unit economics: For a representative $X booking, compute provider fee (12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat for small (≤$150), mid ($300–$600), and large (>$1,000) bookings.
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits. Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing organic relevance.
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10–40%), chargebacks (0.2–0.6%), cancellations (3–10%), and promotions adoption (5–25%) to see contribution margin swings.
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3–6 month lag. Reuse maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand, apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.
