Section 10 — Launch Playbooks & Checklists (10.0–10.8)

Generated on 2025-11-04 22:52:27 UTC

Each sub‑section below is a detailed operational playbook (≥2,500 words) aligned to Sections 1–9.

§10.0 — Alpha → Beta → GA Readiness Checklists

§10.0 — Alpha → Beta → GA Readiness Checklists

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Gate each phase with objective, measurable criteria that reflect trust, money, performance, and usability.
• Prevent premature scaling by requiring admin operability and auditability before GA.
• Create clear ownership and escalation across squads for go/no‑go decisions.

Alpha Exit (internal users + selected creators):
□ Core loop works: search → inquiry → booking → deliverables manifest → acceptance → payout queued.
□ Admin: support can amend receipts, issue partial refunds, and view audits without engineering help.
□ Trust: IDV on; Safe‑Mode default; moderation queue staffing plan; appeals path.
□ Money: ACH enabled in sandbox; card 3DS tested; buyer fee math and provider fee discounts validated.
□ Data: §5 events land in Gold tables; dashboards for S→I, I→B, GMV live; DQ gates pass.
□ Docs: help‑center drafts for refunds, Safe‑Mode, deliverables manifest; support macros.
□ Flags: list of city gates and blast radii documented; rollback plans linked.

Beta Entry (Houston public beta):
□ Invite list seeded: 300–500 verified providers across roles; demand waitlist activated.
□ Support staffed for local hours; Trust trained on playbooks; finance close daily green for 7 days.
□ Tax engine on for allowlisted Texas rules; receipts itemize taxes where applicable.
□ Promotions disabled by default; holdouts and caps configured for later v1.
□ Performance SLOs met for search, messaging, checkout; synthetics are green.

GA Entry (Houston):
□ KPIs hit: S→I ≥ 20%, I→B ≥ 35%, repeat bookings ≥ 30% at 60 days.
□ Dispute loss rate ≤ target; payout latency ≤ 48h; moderation SLA met.
□ Promotions v1 on with caps; ROAS median ≥ 2.5×; invalid‑click credit < 7%.
□ Support SLAs achieved for 30 days; knowledge base completion ≥ 90%.
□ Incident drill passed: checkout failover, tax outage, and moderation surge.

Owners & Roles:
• GM (city) — owns go/no‑go and stakeholder comms.
• Product leads — own feature flags and acceptance criteria.
• Trust lead — owns safety SLAs and appeals.
• Finance lead — owns daily close, payouts, tax receipts.
• SRE — owns SLOs, incident drills, and rollback tests.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• Alpha and Beta dashboards with S→I, I→B, GMV, payout latency, dispute rates, moderation SLAs.
• Error budgets per surface (search, messaging, checkout): burn tracked in weekly business review.
• Flag registry with owners, blast radii, city gates, and rollback steps; last‑tested timestamp.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Soft launches slip into GA without readiness → enforce hard gates and require sign‑off from Trust and Finance.
• Admin gaps force engineering ops → refuse GA until support can act without code changes.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ All GA gates green for 14 consecutive days.
✓ No Sev‑0s in last 14 days; Sev‑1 MTTR within target; drill passed in last 30 days.
✓ Help‑center content audited; macros cover top 20 issues.

Scenario Playbook — Moderation backlog at Beta:
Trigger: Unreviewed queue > threshold for >6 hours
Response: Enable stricter Safe‑Mode; deploy extra moderators; add queue limits; tune classifier thresholds.
Roll‑back/Forward: Return thresholds; publish learnings; adjust appeals capacity.
Owner: Trust lead | Telemetry: queue_length, SLA breach count, appeal rate | User Copy: “We’re reviewing more submissions than usual. Uploads remain safe but may take longer to appear.”

Scenario Playbook — Checkout latency spike:
Trigger: p95 > target; timeouts increasing
Response: Scale workers; rate‑limit promos; prioritize ACH calls; turn off non‑critical services via flags.
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore gradually; compare error budget burn.
Owner: SRE | Telemetry: p95_checkout, error_rate, SLO burn | User Copy: “Brief delay processing payments; your card will not be charged twice.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.1 — City Turn‑Up Runbook (Supply Seeding, Perks, Pricing Floors)

§10.1 — City Turn‑Up Runbook (Supply Seeding, Perks, Pricing Floors)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Stand up a new city with sufficient verified supply and early demand to avoid empty results.
• Deploy time‑boxed perks and CPC floors matched to local liquidity without rigging ranking.
• Ship the same playbook predictably: verify, seed, promote, measure, iterate.

Pre‑turn‑up (T‑30 → T‑7):
□ Studio partners: 10–20 verified studios; deposit defaults configured; house rules imported.
□ Supply: 300+ ID‑verified providers across roles; 50 Trusted Pro; balanced gender and specialties.
□ Demand: 1,000+ waitlisted buyers; 50+ brand/agency leads; outreach sequences prepped.
□ Pricing floors: local CPC floors for promotions set; featured carousel plan.
□ Help content: city‑specific FAQs; local safety resources; studio access details.

Turn‑up week (T‑7 → T):
□ Press/PR drop; city landing page live with featured creators/studios.
□ Founding city perks activated: 0% buyer fee first booking; –2% provider fee for 60 days.
□ Referral program switch‑on; invite codes distributed to partner studios.
□ Trust staffing extended for local hours; support macros localized.

Post‑turn‑up (T → T+30):
□ Daily stand‑up with city metrics; tune CPC floors; adjust caps; rotate Featured slots.
□ Host creator meetup; collect content for home carousels; capture testimonials.
□ Activate RFP broadcast for brands; monitor response quality; adjust threshold for eligibility.

Owners & Roles:
• City GM — owns overall success, partners, PR.
• Growth lead — owns perks, floors, featured slots.
• Trust lead — owns moderation and safety SLAs in city hours.
• Support lead — owns macro correctness and queue staffing.
• Studios PM — owns deposit & rules configuration.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• City‑level S→I, I→B, GMV, active providers/buyers; promotions adoption & ROAS; studio attach rate.
• Supply heatmap: coverage by neighborhood; search 'no results' rate; bounce rate for first‑time visitors.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Thin supply pockets → targeted invites; perks for under‑represented niches; flexible radius defaults.
• PR blowback on nudity policy → artistic‑only examples page; Safe‑Mode defaults; trained press responses.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Sufficient supply (≥300 ID‑verified) and demand (≥1,000 waitlist) in place.
✓ Support and Trust staffing schedules confirmed for local hours.
✓ Perks, floors, and featured modules toggled and measured with caps.

Scenario Playbook — Uneven neighborhood coverage:
Trigger: Searches returning <10 results in key districts
Response: Targeted outreach and incentives; Featured rotation weight to uncovered areas.
Roll‑back/Forward: Normalize rotation once coverage improves.
Owner: City GM | Telemetry: no_results_rate, results_count_by_zip | User Copy: “We’re expanding coverage in your area—new creators arriving daily.”

Scenario Playbook — Featured slots underperform:
Trigger: CTR < target for 3 days
Response: Swap creatives (portfolio picks), adjust slot order, test copy on ribbons.
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore prior set if CTR worsens.
Owner: Growth | Telemetry: featured_impr, featured_ctr, inquiries_from_featured | User Copy: N/A (UI visual only)

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.2 — Safety & Trust Launch Checklist (IDV/BG Readiness, Moderation SLAs)

§10.2 — Safety & Trust Launch Checklist (IDV/BG Readiness, Moderation SLAs)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Ensure safety systems are ready and staffed before public exposure.
• Align ID verification, background checks, Safe‑Mode, and moderation to city‑specific risk patterns.
• Document adverse‑action and appeals so decisions are consistent and defensible.

ID Verification (IDV):
□ Vendor SLA tested; fallback flow documented; fraud heuristics tuned for local IDs.
□ Eligibility rules: Instant Book gated by IDV; Verified‑only search filter returns correct results.
□ Privacy: PII vault operational; admin masked views; access logs audited.

Background Checks (Trusted Pro):
□ Consent screens live; pre‑adverse/adverse templates localized; waiting periods per FCRA.
□ Badge logic integrated with search ranking tie‑break and provider fee nudge (where applicable).
□ Subsidy program configured for first cohort; budget caps set.

Moderation & Safe‑Mode:
□ Classifier thresholds tuned; artistic‑only examples published; appeals workflow tested.
□ Queue staffing plan with on‑call escalation; SLA dashboards live; content templates stocked.
□ Harassment/doXXing macros; emergency law‑enforcement flow rehearsed.

Owners & Roles:
• Trust lead — overall safety posture; moderation and appeals.
• Legal — FCRA compliance; policy approval.
• Data — classifier thresholds; safety telemetry.
• Support — macro training; triage playbooks.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• Moderation SLA (time to action), appeal reversal rate, report rate per 1,000 legs, IB suppression count.
• IDV completion rate; Trusted Pro adoption; safety incidents trend.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Over‑moderation → creator churn; mitigate with clear examples and appeals.
• Under‑moderation → safety risk; mitigate with queue staffing and thresholds.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Moderation SLA met in dry runs; appeal path validated.
✓ IDV flows stable; Trusted Pro notices correct; badge logic live.
✓ Safe‑Mode default for guests verified; examples page published.

Scenario Playbook — IDV vendor latency:
Trigger: p95 > threshold
Response: Switch to fallback; queue retries; inform users; prioritize Instant Book candidates.
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to normal when SLA restored.
Owner: Trust | Telemetry: idv_latency, idv_failure_rate | User Copy: “Identity checks are taking longer than usual. Your verification will complete shortly.”

Scenario Playbook — Harassment spike after PR:
Trigger: Reports > baseline × 3
Response: Triage macros; temporary rate limits; visible enforcement on egregious cases.
Roll‑back/Forward: Lift limits after sustained normal levels.
Owner: Trust/Support | Telemetry: report_rate, action_SLA | User Copy: “We’re actively addressing increased reports. Thanks for your patience.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.

§10.3 — Payments & Tax Go‑Live Checklist (Test Plans & Contingency)

§10.3 — Payments & Tax Go‑Live Checklist (Test Plans & Contingency)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Prove money moves correctly before opening the floodgates.
• Keep contingency playbooks for processor or tax engine incidents.
• Ensure receipts, payouts, and reconciliations are audit‑ready.

Processor Readiness:
□ Card: auth, capture, partial refund, full refund, dispute webhook; 3DS challenge test; card update flows.
□ ACH: link, micro‑deposit fallback, return codes, buyer fee reduction, retry logic.
□ Payouts: bank connect, reserve holds, Early Payout per‑use, failed payout retry.

Tax Engine Readiness:
□ Quotes by state allowlist; latency SLO met; credit memos for refunds; outage banner fallback.
□ Receipts: itemized tax per leg; deposit auth not taxed; captured deposit taxed as required.

Reconciliation:
□ Daily close: match processor settlements; promotions wallet charges; tax exports; variance alarms.
□ Admin tools: amended receipts; ledger views; chargeback kit templates.

Owners & Roles:
• Finance lead — reconciliation and receipts.
• Payments PM/Eng — processor integration and webhooks.
• Tax PM — engine configuration and allowlists.
• Support — money macros; dispute intake.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• Checkout success rate; tax quote success/latency; payout latency; settlement variance; chargeback win rate.
• ACH adoption and effect on buyer fee vs processor cost.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Processor outage → ACH/card fallback; queue and retry; disable promos if needed to protect performance.
• Tax miscalculation → disable tax in affected state via allowlist; message users; reconcile nightly.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ 14 consecutive days of green daily close; variance within tolerance.
✓ End‑to‑end test scenarios pass for both legs (talent and studio when enabled).
✓ Chargeback kit demonstrably complete; templates published.

Scenario Playbook — Tax engine partial outage:
Trigger: Quote failures > threshold
Response: Enable allowlist bypass for affected states; banner copy at checkout; capture order with pending tax.
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑quote and amend receipts post‑outage; notify users.
Owner: Tax PM | Telemetry: tax_quote_latency, tax_quote_error_rate | User Copy: “We’re calculating taxes after checkout due to a temporary issue—you’ll receive an updated receipt.”

Scenario Playbook — Payout queue stuck:
Trigger: No payouts 'Sent' in last 2 hours with pending items
Response: Pause new payouts; investigate webhook backlog; trigger manual retries; communicate on payouts page.
Roll‑back/Forward: Resume queue; audit duplicate guards.
Owner: Payments Eng | Telemetry: payout_status_counts, webhook_lag | User Copy: “Your payout is delayed while we process a queue issue. No action is required.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.

• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.

§10.4 — Support Readiness (Macros, Refund Calculators, SLAs)

§10.4 — Support Readiness (Macros, Refund Calculators, SLAs)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Equip Support to resolve the majority of issues without engineering.
• Publish macros, calculators, and knowledge so outcomes are consistent and fast.
• Measure and staff to SLAs that match city hours and expected volume.

Tooling & Macros:
□ Refund calculator integrated; partial and multi‑leg support; time‑band logic.
□ Dispute intake wizard; chargeback evidence builder; attachment checklist.
□ Moderation escalation buttons; PII redaction; account limits controls.
□ DM limits and spam controls; identity re‑verification triggers.

Knowledge Base:
□ Top 50 issues covered; plain‑English answers; screenshots of admin steps.
□ Money articles: refunds, tax, deposits, chargebacks; trust articles: Safe‑Mode, IDV, BG.
□ City‑specific FAQs: perks, studios, accessibility info.

Staffing & SLAs:
□ Queue size forecasts; shifts aligned to city hours; escalation paths to Trust/Finance.
□ FRT/FRR targets by priority; on‑call coverage for incidents; training completion records.

Owners & Roles:
• Support lead — macros, staffing, training.
• Trust liaison — safety escalations and training.
• Finance liaison — money macros and approvals.
• Product — admin feature readiness and gaps.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• FRT/FRR; reopen rate; macro usage rate; CSAT; SLA breaches; ticket categories and trends.
• Deflection: % resolved via knowledge base before ticket creation.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Under‑tooled support → backlog and inconsistent outcomes; mitigate with calculators and macros.
• Over‑escalation → engineer toil; mitigate with clear paths and admin powers.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Macros published and versioned; refund calculator validated with finance; training complete.
✓ SLAs met during dry run; escalation and paging tested; knowledge base >90% coverage of top issues.

Scenario Playbook — Refund volume spike:
Trigger: Refund tickets > baseline × 2
Response: Enable queue filters; adjust macros; preemptive emails for known issues; expand staffing windows.
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to standard macros; retrospective root cause analysis.
Owner: Support lead | Telemetry: refund_ticket_rate, SLA_breaches | User Copy: “We’ve received your refund request and are prioritizing it. Expect an update soon.”

Scenario Playbook — Spam wave in DMs:
Trigger: New‑conversation sends with low response rate spike
Response: Tighten rate limits; require IDV for new outreach; update abuse heuristics; temporary DM credit freeze.
Roll‑back/Forward: Gradual relaxation with monitors.
Owner: Trust liaison | Telemetry: dm_send_rate, spam_reports | User Copy: “We’re limiting new messages briefly to reduce spam while maintaining creator safety.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.5 — Promotions Go‑Live (Caps, Floors, Holdouts, QA)

§10.5 — Promotions Go‑Live (Caps, Floors, Holdouts, QA)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Launch paid visibility without harming search relevance or trust.
• Prove ROAS with holdouts; keep density and frequency caps enforced.
• Give providers clear setup, reporting, and refunds for invalid clicks.

Pre‑launch:
□ Eligibility gates (IDV, Rep ≥ 70, no strikes) enforced; QS formula tuned; CPC floors by role/city set.
□ Density caps: ≤2 boosted in top‑20; ≤1 above the fold; frequency caps per buyer/session/day.
□ Holdout cells configured (5–10%); dashboards wired; invalid‑click detection live with auto‑crediting.

Provider UX:
□ Boost setup wizard; suggested bid range; estimated clicks; QS improvement checklist.
□ Reporting: impressions, clicks, CTR, CPC, inquiries, bookings, GMV, ROAS; alerts for budget depletion and invalid clicks.

QA & Monitoring:
□ End‑to‑end click tracking; fraud heuristics test; miscategorization auto‑pause; city ops pricing governance.

Owners & Roles:
• Growth PM — product settings and UX.
• Trust — eligibility and abuse handling.
• Finance — revenue recognition; invalid‑click credits accounting.
• City Ops — floors and featured pricing per city.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• CPC, CTR, QS distribution; ROAS median; invalid‑click credit %; buyer hide/report on promoted cards.
• Organic search KPIs unaffected: S→I, I→B, satisfaction; measure cannibalization risk.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Pay‑to‑win perception → strong labeling, relevance match, caps; eligibility bars.
• Fraud → auto‑credits; throttle offenders; anomaly alerts; manual review for patterns.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Holdout ROAS ≥ 2.5× median; invalid‑click credits < 7%; organic KPIs stable within guardrails.
✓ Provider setup and reporting successful in dry run; billing via wallet correct.

Scenario Playbook — Invalid clicks surge:
Trigger: Invalid rate > upper bound
Response: Tighten fraud filters; auto‑credit; temporarily reduce density; notify affected providers.
Roll‑back/Forward: Relax once normal; publish learning.
Owner: Growth/Trust | Telemetry: invalid_click_rate, ROAS | User Copy: “We issued credits for suspicious clicks while we improve detection—thanks for your patience.”

Scenario Playbook — Provider backlash on labeling:
Trigger: Feedback cites confusion or distrust
Response: Improve 'Promoted' tooltip; publish help page; survey to validate clarity.
Roll‑back/Forward: A/B previous label copy if metrics regress.
Owner: Growth PM | Telemetry: buyer_hide_rate, help_center_views | User Copy: “Promoted results match your filters and are clearly marked to keep search fair.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.

• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.6 — Communications Plan (Email/SMS Sequences, Help Center)

§10.6 — Communications Plan (Email/SMS Sequences, Help Center)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Coordinate launch communications that set correct expectations, drive adoption, and reduce support burden.
• Use lifecycle sequences for providers and buyers tied to real behaviors.
• Keep help‑center content synchronized with UI and policy changes.

Provider lifecycle (examples):
□ Welcome (IDV + how to publish first package).
□ First inquiry → 'How to convert to booking' tips.
□ First booking → 'Deliverables manifest & acceptance' checklist.
□ Trusted Pro pass → badge benefits + Boost coupon.
□ Churn risk → nudge with availability tips and price guidance.

Buyer lifecycle (examples):
□ Welcome → search tips + Safe‑Mode explainer.
□ First booking → 'What to expect' and refund windows; ACH discount callout.
□ Post‑booking → review request; referral invite.
□ RFP broadcasts → 'How to write a brief' guide.

Help‑center & status updates:
□ Visual examples for artistic‑only boundaries; Safe‑Mode toggle guide.
□ Tax and money articles; city perks pages; studio deposit explanations.
□ Status page for incidents; templates for banners and in‑app notices.

Owners & Roles:
• Marketing — sequences and brand voice.
• Product — in‑app copy and help‑center alignment.
• Support — macros and FAQ freshness; deflection tracking.
• Trust — safety copy and escalation comms.
• Finance — money/tax copy accuracy.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• Open/click rates; conversions from emails; deflection %; NPS changes; complaint rates; unsubscribes.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Over‑emailing → unsubscribes; mitigate with behavior‑based triggers and caps.
• Policy confusion → keep examples fresh and visible; avoid legalese.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ All core sequences QA’d; help‑center synchronized with UI; status page playbooks ready.
✓ Comms calendar coordinated with city turn‑ups and feature flags.

Scenario Playbook — Press spike:
Trigger: Traffic surge and PR mentions
Response: Pin welcome and safety posts; adjust sequences to onboard quickly; ensure support has pinned macros.
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to normal cadence.
Owner: Marketing/Product | Telemetry: bounce_rate, activation_rate | User Copy: “New here? Start with how booking works in 3 steps.”

Scenario Playbook — Email deliverability dip:
Trigger: Inbox placement declines
Response: Warmup IPs; prune lists; adjust sending windows; improve DKIM/SPF; diversify to in‑app and SMS for critical comms.
Roll‑back/Forward: Reintroduce segments gradually.
Owner: Marketing | Telemetry: bounce/complaint rates | User Copy: N/A (backend deliverability)

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.

§10.7 — Incident Command & Rollback Drills (Feature‑Flag Recipes)

§10.7 — Incident Command & Rollback Drills (Feature‑Flag Recipes)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Establish an incident framework with clear roles, SEV levels, and rollback powers.
• Practice drills that reflect our highest‑risk surfaces: checkout, tax, moderation, promotions.
• Document feature‑flag recipes that safely degrade functionality.

Roles & SEV:
□ Incident Commander (IC) + Comms + Ops + Eng; SEV‑0/1/2 matrix with SLAs.
□ Pager rotations; escalation tree; status page policies; customer comms templates.

Flag recipes:
□ Disable promotions; reduce density to zero; keep organic ranking intact.
□ Checkout degrade: force card when ACH engine degraded; allow 'pending tax' path with banner.
□ Safe‑Mode hardening: increase thresholds; pause new media ingestion; keep messaging live.
□ Admin controls: kill‑switches for money moves require two‑person approval.

Drills:
□ Quarterly disaster day with switchbacks; capture MTTA/MTTR; retrospective with action items.
□ Vendor outage simulations: processor, tax, IDV; confirm fallbacks.
□ Data corruption simulation: DQ gates trigger; freeze dashboards; recover from backups.

Owners & Roles:
• SRE/Platform — incident framework and drills.
• Product leads — flag recipes and blast radii.
• Trust/Finance — guardrails for money/safety degradations.
• Support — comms and macros.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• MTTA/MTTR; incidents by SEV; error budget burn; flags toggled; status page updates; support volume surge and SLA.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Unclear authority in crisis → written runbooks; regular practice.
• Regression after rollback → smoke tests; post‑incident QA; changelog discipline.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ At least one multi‑surface drill passed per quarter.
✓ All flag recipes tested in sandbox and once in production under controlled conditions.
✓ Status page and comms templates verified; on‑call schedules posted.

Scenario Playbook — Processor partial outage:
Trigger: Spike in card declines; webhook lag
Response: Prefer ACH; pause promotions; display safe banner; queue retries; coordinate with processor.
Roll‑back/Forward: Enable normal flows gradually; audit duplicates.
Owner: SRE/Payments | Telemetry: decline_rate, webhook_lag | User Copy: “Some card payments are impacted—try ACH or retry shortly.”

Scenario Playbook — Moderation surge from viral post:
Trigger: Queue length > threshold
Response: Tighten Safe‑Mode; pause new media; reassign staff; inform users.
Roll‑back/Forward: Reopen after backlog clears.
Owner: Trust | Telemetry: queue_length, SLA | User Copy: “We’re reviewing more uploads than usual; thanks for your patience.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.

• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.8 — Post‑Launch Review Template (7/30/90‑Day)

§10.8 — Post‑Launch Review Template (7/30/90‑Day)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free, monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without code changes.

Goals:
• Turn launch learnings into process and product improvements quickly.
• Hold owners accountable for outcomes with clear metrics and action items.
• Decide whether to expand to the next city based on evidence.

7‑Day Review:
□ Adoption: active providers/buyers vs targets; first‑booking rates; activation funnels.
□ Trust: report rate; moderation SLA; IDV adoption; early safety incidents.
□ Money: checkout success; payout latency; daily close; tax reconciliation.
□ Support: FRT/FRR; top tickets; macro gaps.
□ Promotions (if on): adoption; ROAS; invalid‑click credits.

30‑Day Review:
□ Conversion: S→I and I→B trends; repeat bookings; cancellations and reasons.
□ Economics: take‑rate mix; processor costs; promotions contribution; COGS vs plan.
□ Quality: dispute loss rate; review sentiment; reputation score distribution.
□ Ops: staffing vs SLA; incident count; flag drift; help‑center coverage.

90‑Day Review:
□ Cohort retention curves; contribution margin; CAC payback in city; referrals and organic loops.
□ Safety stability; appeals accuracy; Trusted Pro share; studios attach and deposit claims.
□ Decision: scale promotions floors? Open nearby city? Adjust perks?

Owners & Roles:
• City GM — overall; compile review.
• Product & Data — KPIs and analysis.
• Trust & Support — safety and ops analysis.
• Finance — economics and close; tax reconciliation.
• Growth — promotions and CAC payback.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:
• Dashboards per §5; appendix with definitions; DQ report; cohort charts; incident summaries.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Celebratory bias → insist on counter‑metrics; include 'what went wrong' section.
• Action‑less reviews → require named owners and due dates for every item.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Action plan approved with owners and deadlines for the next 30 days.
✓ Decision recorded on city expansion or adjustments to floors/perks/promotions.
✓ Review doc archived with links to dashboards, audits, and incident reports.

Scenario Playbook — Dispute loss rate out of bounds:
Trigger: Loss rate > target for 2 months
Response: Tighten SOW defaults; improve manifest guidance; enhance chargeback kits; educate users with comms.
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑evaluate after 30 days; iterate solutions.
Owner: Finance/Product | Telemetry: dispute_loss_rate, refund_rate | User Copy: “We’ve clarified deliverables and refunds to reduce misunderstandings.”

Scenario Playbook — Promotions ROAS under target:
Trigger: ROAS median < 2.5×
Response: Adjust QS weights; lower density; improve provider guidance; test floors; pause low‑quality cohorts.
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore after lift.
Owner: Growth | Telemetry: ROAS_distribution, QS | User Copy: “Tips to improve your boost performance are now in your dashboard.”

Implementation Notes:
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches for money and safety features with two‑person approval.
• Admin Operability: No checklist is 'done' unless Support can resolve the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required actions with an audit trail.
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases (ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause experiments when guardrails breach.
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

Section 11 — Risk Register & Mitigations (11.0–11.8)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:18:34 UTC

Each sub‑section below is a detailed risk blueprint (≥2,500 words) aligned to Sections 1–10.

§11.0 — Risk Taxonomy, Scoring & Governance (Likelihood × Impact, RPN, Ownership)

§11.0 — Risk Taxonomy, Scoring & Governance (Likelihood × Impact, RPN, Ownership)

Risk & Process Disclaimer: This section is an internal risk‑management blueprint. It does not constitute legal, tax, or security advice. Coordinate with counsel and security leaders before externalizing any policy or committing to obligations. All examples are illustrative and must be adapted to the realities measured in Section 5 dashboards.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace launch; subscription‑free start; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are exchanged via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments release on acceptance. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags. Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, and full audit trails.

Goals:
• Create a shared language for risk across product, trust, finance, legal, and ops.
• Standardize scoring (likelihood × impact) and prioritization (RPN) to focus on material risks.
• Define ownership, cadence, and escalation paths; integrate with flags and city gates.

Risk statements (top of mind):
• Mis‑moderation or unclear public‑content boundaries leading to press/regulatory risk.
• Payments outage or mis‑settlement leading to user harm and trust loss.
• Chargeback/fraud ring increasing losses and throttling growth.
• PII exposure or vendor breach causing legal and reputational damage.
• Tax miscollection due to misclassification or engine errors causing financial exposure.
• Operational overload (support/trust) at launch reducing quality and SLAs.

Primary causes & contributing factors:
• Ambiguous policy or incomplete training; lack of examples in §8.2.
• Insufficient end‑to‑end money testing; single processor dependency.
• Weak off‑platform leakage controls; lack of buyer education at checkout.
• Over‑privileged admin roles; missing JIT elevation; vendor misconfigurations.
• Incorrect item mappings in tax engine; gaps in allowlist rollout.
• Underestimated volume; insufficient macros; incomplete admin tools.

Leading indicators & early warning signals:
• Spike in appeals overturning moderation decisions; media mentions with negative framing.
• Checkout p95 latency and error spikes; rise in payout 'failed' states.
• Chargeback rate > baseline; clustering by BIN/issuer or geography.
• Admin PII unmask spikes; vendor SOC/pentest exceptions; unusual export volumes.
• Reconciliation variances by state; tax quote error rates; support tickets citing tax confusion.
• SLA breaches in Support/Trust; increased reopen rates; macro usage slump.

Preventive controls & mitigations:
• Publish examples and Safe‑Mode defaults; require two‑person review for edge policies.
• Multi‑processor readiness; drills; ACH fallback and banners.
• In‑chat off‑platform warnings; escrow value copy; IB incentives for verified users.
• RBAC, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals; vendor due diligence; PII vault.
• Tax engine allowlists; nightly reconciliations; receipt itemization tests.
• Staffing buffers; calculators/macros; deflection via help‑center; admin operability gates.

Incident playbooks (summary):
• Moderation surge → raise Safe‑Mode thresholds; add moderators; publish guidance.
• Processor incident → switch rails; queue retries; pause promotions; status page updates.
• Fraud ring → tighten DM limits; require IDV; suppress Instant Book; manual review.
• PII incident → incident command; containment; counsel; notifications; post‑mortem.
• Tax outage → allowlist bypass; pending tax receipts; reconciliation corrections.
• Support overload → triage macros; priority queues; temporary hours extension; surge staffing.

RACI / Owners:
• Risk DRI (cross‑functional), City GM, Trust Lead, Payments PM, Tax PM, SRE, Support Lead, Legal.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Risk Priority Number (RPN) tallied monthly; top‑10 risks reviewed in exec meeting.
• Time to mitigation for red risks; number of incidents by SEV; audit action completion rate.

Thresholds & triggers (Go/No‑Go, rollback, escalation):
• Any red risk (RPN ≥ 16 on 1–5×1–5 with impact weighted) triggers weekly review and action plan.
• Two consecutive months with rising RPN in the same category triggers board visibility.

Dependencies & assumptions:
• Section 5 dashboards; Section 8 policies; Section 10 incident drills; Admin §4.14 tooling.

Acceptance checklist (risk under control when):
□ Risk register live with owners; reviewed monthly; versioned.
□ Scoring rubric published; examples for each score; training completed.
□ Top‑10 risks have explicit mitigations, flags, and playbooks.

Scenario Deep‑Dive — Conflicting risk mitigations:
Context: A mitigation for promotions harms search fairness KPIs.
Trigger: Organic S→I drops > 10% after promotions tweak.
Immediate actions: Revert via flag; expand holdout; convene cross‑functional review; adjust QS weight.
Communication: Internal only; no user comms unless visible changes persist.
Rollback/Forward: Restore prior QS; publish learnings in registry.
Owner: Growth + Product | Telemetry: S→I, buyer hide/report rates, ROAS | Evidence: A/B logs; click maps; holdout diffs

Execution Notes:
• Every risk has a dashboard tile with an owner, a definition of the denominator, and a weekly narrative. • Risk reviews pair with §10 post‑launch 7/30/90‑day reviews and §8 compliance calendar. • Where a risk spans multiple squads, the city GM or Risk DRI chairs the review; actions have due dates. • We prefer reversible changes (flags) and narrow blast radius (city gates). • We avoid 'security by obscurity'; we publish clear user guidance, train staff, and keep audit trails for all sensitive actions. • The risk register itself is versioned; changes record rationale and observed metrics.

Execution Notes:

§11.1 — Product & UX Risks (Adoption, Clarity, Multi‑Role Complexity, Deliverables)

§11.1 — Product & UX Risks (Adoption, Clarity, Multi‑Role Complexity, Deliverables)

Risk & Process Disclaimer: This section is an internal risk‑management blueprint. It does not constitute legal, tax, or security advice. Coordinate with counsel and security leaders before externalizing any policy or committing to obligations. All examples are illustrative and must be adapted to the realities measured in Section 5 dashboards.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace launch; subscription‑free start; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are exchanged via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments release on acceptance. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags. Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, and full audit trails.

Goals:
• Identify user‑experience pitfalls that slow adoption or create confusion.
• Ensure multi‑role profiles, search filters, and booking flows remain clear and fast.
• Prevent scope creep and feature load that harms initial simplicity.

Risk statements (top of mind):
• Multi‑role profile confusion causes poor discovery and low conversion.
• Over‑complex search overwhelms new buyers; defaults hide relevant results.
• Deliverables manifest flow is too heavy, causing drop‑offs and disputes later.
• Reschedule/Change Order UX leads to off‑platform renegotiations and leakage.
• Boards/following become noisy; feed devolves into spam; DM fatigue increases.

Primary causes & contributing factors:
• Insufficient labeling between roles; poor tabbing; mixed reviews across roles.
• Too many filters surfaced by default; lack of presets; unclear tooltips.
• Manifest requirements unclear; large file flows intimidating; external links not well explained.
• Change fees and time bands not visible; provider controls not transparent.
• No rate limits; weak relevance; missing foldering and muting controls.

Leading indicators & early warning signals:
• High bounce on profile tabs; low click‑through to booking from role pages.
• Filter usage spikes with declining S→I; help‑center views for 'how to search'.
• Abandoned 'Add deliverables' step; disputes citing 'not as described'.
• Change orders initiated off‑platform; refund tickets citing confusion.
• Hide/mute rates; follow churn; DM response time increases; spam reports.

Preventive controls & mitigations:
• Clear role tabs, separate reviews per role, cross‑linking; role‑specific landing pages.
• Beginner mode with presets; advanced filter drawer; definitions chips; engagement sliders.
• Lightweight manifest defaults + 'external link manifest' explainer; examples and templates.
• Inline price math; protected change order flow; audit trail; lock messaging until accepted.
• Foldered follows; rate limits; mute; relevance tuning; 'quality bar' for feed posts.

Incident playbooks (summary):
• Search simplification AB test; remove low‑value filters; increase presets.
• Deliverables tutorial video; acceptance window guidance; macro for 'how manifests work'.
• DM spam spike: tighten sends; require IDV for outreach; adjust credits per §3.2 launch spec.

RACI / Owners:
• Product (Profiles/Search/Booking), Design, Data, Trust liaison, Support.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• S→I and I→B per role; click‑through from tabs; change order on‑platform rate vs off‑platform signals.
• Dispute rate 'not as described'; manifest completion rate; feed engagement health.

Thresholds & triggers (Go/No‑Go, rollback, escalation):
• Drop in S→I > 10% over 7 days; feed hide rate > threshold; off‑platform signals increase.

Dependencies & assumptions:
• Role‑aware profiles (§1.1), search filters (§1.2), deliverables (§3.6), messaging (§1.4), analytics (§1.6).

Acceptance checklist (risk under control when):
□ Role tabs and separate reviews confirmed; presets live; tooltips tested with users.
□ Change order UX integrated; macros and help content published; telemetry validated.

Scenario Deep‑Dive — Search paralysis:
Context: Buyers apply too many filters, zero results.
Trigger: No‑results rate up in key cohorts.
Immediate actions: Suggest relaxations; show 'near matches'; auto‑save boards for later.
Communication: In‑UI nudges; help article link.
Rollback/Forward: Restore stricter defaults if irrelevant results rise.
Owner: Search PM | Telemetry: no_results_rate, CTR | Evidence: Filter combinations; session replays (privacy‑safe)

Execution Notes:
• Every risk has a dashboard tile with an owner, a definition of the denominator, and a weekly narrative. • Risk reviews pair with §10 post‑launch 7/30/90‑day reviews and §8 compliance calendar. • Where a risk spans multiple squads, the city GM or Risk DRI chairs the review; actions have due dates. • We prefer reversible changes (flags) and narrow blast radius (city gates). • We avoid 'security by obscurity'; we publish clear user guidance, train staff, and keep audit trails for all sensitive actions. • The risk register itself is versioned; changes record rationale and observed metrics.

Execution Notes:
• Every risk has a dashboard tile with an owner, a definition of the denominator, and a weekly narrative. • Risk reviews pair with §10 post‑launch 7/30/90‑day reviews and §8 compliance calendar. • Where a risk spans multiple squads, the city GM or Risk DRI chairs the review; actions have due dates. • We prefer reversible changes (flags) and narrow blast radius (city gates). • We avoid 'security by obscurity'; we publish clear user guidance, train staff, and keep audit trails for all sensitive actions. • The risk register itself is versioned; changes record rationale and observed metrics.

Execution Notes:

§11.2 — Trust & Safety Risks (Harassment, Impersonation, Off‑Platform Harm, Policy Drift)

§11.2 — Trust & Safety Risks (Harassment, Impersonation, Off‑Platform Harm, Policy Drift)

Risk & Process Disclaimer: This section is an internal risk‑management blueprint. It does not constitute legal, tax, or security advice. Coordinate with counsel and security leaders before externalizing any policy or committing to obligations. All examples are illustrative and must be adapted to the realities measured in Section 5 dashboards.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace launch; subscription‑free start; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict eligibility and caps. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are exchanged via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments release on acceptance. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags. Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, and full audit trails.

Goals:
• Reduce likelihood and impact of safety incidents involving harassment, doxxing, impersonation, or off‑platform harm.
• Keep public content within artistic‑only boundaries; maintain Safe‑Mode defaults for guests.
• Ensure consistent moderation with appeals and examples to avoid drift.

Risk statements (top of mind):
• Harassment/doxxing in DMs or feeds leading to user harm and PR blowback.
• Impersonation or fake profiles enabling scams or unsafe bookings.
• Underage appearance risk; failure to detect minors in media or accounts.
• Policy drift causing inconsistent enforcement across cities and moderators.
• Off‑platform incidents tied to bookings (safety at shoots).

Primary causes & contributing factors:
• Insufficient rate limits, weak report tools; unclear consequences.
• Weak IDV adoption; lax selfie‑to‑ID checks; stock images in profiles.
• Lack of classifier support; no birthdate consistency checks.
• Inadequate training; missing examples; subjective decisions without guidance.
• Poor venue controls; lack of trusted contact features; unclear house rules.

Leading indicators & early warning signals:
• Spike in harassment reports; higher block rates; trending topics calling out the platform.
• Chargeback narratives citing impersonation; increased 'scam' reports.
• Reports about age; 'minor' flags from models; vendor alerts.
• Appeal reversal rate high; inter‑moderator variance in similar cases.
• Safety reports post‑booking; law‑enforcement contacts; negative reviews citing safety.

Preventive controls & mitigations:
• Stronger rate limits; spam heuristics; 'report & block' prominent; doxxing macro and removal.
• IDV gate for Instant Book; selfie checks; image forensics on profile media.
• Age checks in onboarding; minors policy training; escalations to T&S lead.
• Policy examples gallery; moderation calibration sessions; QA on decisions.
• Trusted contact links; area‑share during booking; studio verification; house rules.

Incident playbooks (summary):
• Harassment surge: rate limit new senders; lock threads pending review; publish anti‑harassment stance.
• Impersonation ring: mass review of recent signups; require IDV before messaging; remove offenders.
• Minor risk: freeze account; verify; remove media; contact authorities if required.

RACI / Owners:
• Trust lead, Moderation team, Support, Legal liaison, Studios PM.

Instrumentation & success metrics:
• Harassment reports per 1,000 legs; appeal reversals; impersonation takedowns; IDV adoption; safety incident rate.

Thresholds & triggers (Go/No‑Go, rollback, escalation):
• Harassment ≥ threshold → enable stricter defaults; impersonation cluster → require IDV for new DMs.

Dependencies & assumptions:
• Section 8 policies; §4.14 admin moderation tools; §1.5 signals; §3.4 verification monetization.

Acceptance checklist (risk under control when):
□ Calibrated examples live; moderation training complete; appeal SLAs met; trusted contact & area‑share live.

Scenario Deep‑Dive — Coordinated harassment campaign:
Context: External group targets creators after media coverage.
Trigger: Reports ×3 baseline; social mentions spike.
Immediate actions: Enable stricter DM limits; block repeat abusive accounts; comms with safety tips; liaise with PR/legal.
Communication: Status page + help‑center; direct messages to affected users.
Rollback/Forward: Return to normal limits when stable; retrospective.
Owner: Trust + Comms | Telemetry: report_rate, block_rate | Evidence: Report logs; message excerpts (redacted)

Execution Notes:
• Every risk has a dashboard tile with an owner, a definition of the denominator, and a weekly narrative. • Risk reviews pair with §10 post‑launch 7/30/90‑day reviews and §8 compliance calendar. • Where a risk spans multiple squads, the city GM or Risk DRI chairs the review; actions have due dates. • We prefer reversible changes (flags) and narrow blast radius (city gates). • We avoid 'security by obscurity'; we publish clear user guidance, train staff, and keep audit trails for all sensitive actions. • The risk register itself is versioned; changes record rationale and observed metrics.
