§12.9 — Phase 8: Staffing & Budget Alignment (Squads, Vendors, SLAs)

§12.9 — Phase 8: Staffing & Budget Alignment (Squads, Vendors, SLAs)

Roadmap Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document. Dates are placeholders and will firm up as Section 5 telemetry validates conversion and quality gates. All items ship behind flags and city allowlists. Nothing herein creates external commitments.

Context & Alignment: US‑only creative marketplace; subscription‑free at launch; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with eligibility gates and strict caps; public content limited to artistic‑only (guest Safe‑Mode on by default); deliverables handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments released on acceptance; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks confer Trusted Pro; city‑gated rollout with feature flags; strong Admin Console with least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, and immutable audits.

Timeframe & Scope:
• Updated quarterly; synchronized with Section 9 budgets and Section 10 launches.

Goals:
• Align headcount and vendor spend with phase gates and city expansions.
• Ensure Support/Trust scaling keeps SLAs while avoiding over‑hiring.

Product Themes:
• Lean, phased hiring; vendor consolidation; training and quality guardrails.

Workstreams & Deliverables:
• Squad plans per phase; hiring profiles; onboarding; training; shadowing; QA sign‑off.
• Vendor spend reviews; SLA scorecards; renewal calendar; backups/failovers.
• Support/Trust staffing models; surge plans; knowledge base and macro maintenance cadence.

Feature Flags & City Gates:
• ops.hiring.freeze (when needed), vendor.sla.alerts, support.surge.plan

Dependencies & Inputs:
• Finance budgets (§9), GTM (§2), launches (§10), admin tooling (§4.14).

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Over‑hiring ahead of signals; vendor lock‑in; training gaps; burnout; SLA misses.

Instrumentation & KPIs:
• Runway months; burn multiple; SLA compliance; training completion; macro freshness; vendor uptime vs SLA.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ Hiring unlocks tied to KPIs; vendor SLAs green; support SLAs met with buffers.

Staffing & Ownership:
• Leadership, HR/Recruiting, Finance, City Ops, Support/Trust, Engineering managers.

Milestones & Checkpoints:
• Quarterly headcount review; vendor rationalization; training refreshes; retention checks.

Implementation Notes:
• Flag Discipline: Each capability ships behind a named flag with a runbook, owner, rollback, and blast‑radius notes. Flags default to 'off' in new cities.
• Admin Operability: No workstream is 'done' until admin tools enable Support/Trust/Finance to handle the top 3 edge cases without engineering.
• Copy & Policy: All flows have help‑center articles and email/SMS templates; copy avoids legalese and links to policy examples.
• QA & Drills: Staging mimics production data shapes; drills include processor/tax outages, moderation surges, and incident command handoffs.

• Accessibility: New UI complies with WCAG 2.1 AA; screen‑reader and keyboard paths verified; contrast ratios checked; defects triaged.
• Security & Privacy: PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive admin actions; vendor scopes minimal; audits immutable.
• City Readiness: City‑first artifacts (press kit, creator ambassadors, studio partners) prepared in §10.1 runbook.
• Post‑Launch: 7/30/90‑day reviews convert observations into roadmap changes; flags let us tune by city without forks.

• Flag Discipline: Each capability ships behind a named flag with a runbook, owner, rollback, and blast‑radius notes. Flags default to 'off' in new cities.
• Admin Operability: No workstream is 'done' until admin tools enable Support/Trust/Finance to handle the top 3 edge cases without engineering.
• Copy & Policy: All flows have help‑center articles and email/SMS templates; copy avoids legalese and links to policy examples.
• QA & Drills: Staging mimics production data shapes; drills include processor/tax outages, moderation surges, and incident command handoffs.
• Experimentation: Features that affect marketplace economics (ranking, boosts, fees) include holdouts and guardrails; we measure incremental impact.
• Data Wiring: Events land in Bronze/Silver/Gold (§5); KPIs pull only from Gold with freshness SLOs. Definitions live in a metrics catalog.
• Accessibility: New UI complies with WCAG 2.1 AA; screen‑reader and keyboard paths verified; contrast ratios checked; defects triaged.
• Security & Privacy: PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive admin actions; vendor scopes minimal; audits immutable.
• City Readiness: City‑first artifacts (press kit, creator ambassadors, studio partners) prepared in §10.1 runbook.
• Post‑Launch: 7/30/90‑day reviews convert observations into roadmap changes; flags let us tune by city without forks.

Implementation Notes:
• Flag Discipline: Each capability ships behind a named flag with a runbook, owner, rollback, and blast‑radius notes. Flags default to 'off' in new cities.
• Admin Operability: No workstream is 'done' until admin tools enable Support/Trust/Finance to handle the top 3 edge cases without engineering.

§12.10 — Phase Gates, KPIs & Exit Criteria (Go/No‑Go per Phase & City)

§12.10 — Phase Gates, KPIs & Exit Criteria (Go/No‑Go per Phase & City)

Roadmap Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document. Dates are placeholders and will firm up as Section 5 telemetry validates conversion and quality gates. All items ship behind flags and city allowlists. Nothing herein creates external commitments.

Context & Alignment: US‑only creative marketplace; subscription‑free at launch; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with eligibility gates and strict caps; public content limited to artistic‑only (guest Safe‑Mode on by default); deliverables handled via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments released on acceptance; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional background checks confer Trusted Pro; city‑gated rollout with feature flags; strong Admin Console with least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, and immutable audits.

Timeframe & Scope:
• Applies to all phases; reviewed monthly; ratcheted only after sustained performance.

Goals:
• Make phase transitions objective and auditable with clear, city‑specific thresholds.
• Avoid premature scaling; unlock hiring and spend based on evidence.

Product Themes:
• Evidence‑based progress; city‑gated rollouts; fairness and trust non‑negotiable.

Workstreams & Deliverables:
• Define phase gates for Alpha, Beta, GA, and city expansions; publish in Admin; tie to flags.
• Create board‑level KPI pack (§9.8) with red/yellow/green bands and owners.

Feature Flags & City Gates:
• gate.alpha.exit, gate.beta.exit, gate.ga.entry, gate.city.expand.{city}, gate.promotions.on

Dependencies & Inputs:
• §5 dashboards; §10 drills; §11 risks; §9 financials; §8 policies.

Top Risks & Mitigations:
• Threshold myopia; metric gaming; noisy early data; city differences ignored.

Instrumentation & KPIs:
• Per phase: S→I, I→B, repeat %, dispute loss, payout latency, IDV %, Trusted Pro %, promotions ROAS (if on), support SLA, tax variance.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):
✓ All gates green for the period; no Sev‑0/1; help‑center parity; admin coverage for edge cases; board sign‑off for expansions.

Staffing & Ownership:
• City GM, Product, Trust, Finance, SRE, Data — each signs their gate.

Milestones & Checkpoints:
• Alpha exit; Beta entry; GA entry; City‑2/3 launches; promotions GA; studios beta/GA; mobile GA.

Implementation Notes:
• Flag Discipline: Each capability ships behind a named flag with a runbook, owner, rollback, and blast‑radius notes. Flags default to 'off' in new cities.
• Admin Operability: No workstream is 'done' until admin tools enable Support/Trust/Finance to handle the top 3 edge cases without engineering.
• Copy & Policy: All flows have help‑center articles and email/SMS templates; copy avoids legalese and links to policy examples.
• QA & Drills: Staging mimics production data shapes; drills include processor/tax outages, moderation surges, and incident command handoffs.
• Experimentation: Features that affect marketplace economics (ranking, boosts, fees) include holdouts and guardrails; we measure incremental impact.
• Data Wiring: Events land in Bronze/Silver/Gold (§5); KPIs pull only from Gold with freshness SLOs. Definitions live in a metrics catalog.
• Accessibility: New UI complies with WCAG 2.1 AA; screen‑reader and keyboard paths verified; contrast ratios checked; defects triaged.
• Security & Privacy: PII masked by default; JIT elevation for sensitive admin actions; vendor scopes minimal; audits immutable.
• City Readiness: City‑first artifacts (press kit, creator ambassadors, studio partners) prepared in §10.1 runbook.
• Post‑Launch: 7/30/90‑day reviews convert observations into roadmap changes; flags let us tune by city without forks.

Section 13 — Partnerships & Ecosystem (13.0–13.7)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:42:25 UTC

Each sub‑section is a ≥2,500‑word partner strategy chapter aligned with Sections 1–12.

§13.0 — Partnership Strategy & Evaluation Framework

§13.0 — Partnership Strategy & Evaluation Framework

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Define how we choose, integrate, and scale partners without compromising trust or flexibility.
• Prioritize partners that accelerate conversion (ACH, IDV), safety (BG, studios), and differentiation (social metrics, RFPs).
• Set common legal, security, and commercial patterns to speed negotiation and onboarding.

Target partner segments:
• Money stack partners: processors, ACH, tax engines, payout banks.
• Trust stack partners: ID verification, background checks, e‑signature, moderation tooling.
• Discovery & data partners: social platforms, analytics providers, SEO/media affiliates.
• Supply partners: verified studios, equipment rental, education programs, creator communities.
• Demand partners: brands, agencies, RFP aggregators, small‑business networks.
• Workflow partners: file storage (Drive/Dropbox), calendar, chat/Slack, Zapier‑style automation.

Mutual value proposition:
• Faster, cheaper, safer transactions → better conversion and margins (ACH discounts, stable payouts).
• Higher safety signals → more Instant Book, fewer disputes, better trust and reviews.
• Richer discovery (verified social metrics) → better matching, higher booking value.
• Lower CAC via co‑marketing (studios, schools, brand networks) → cheaper city launches.
• Improved retention via tools users already use (Drive, Dropbox, Calendar, Slack).

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Security posture (SOC, pentest, breach history), data minimization, token scopes, deletion flows.
• Commercial flexibility (no exclusivity, volume tiers, credits for outages, predictable pricing).
• API quality and rate limits; reliability; sandbox support; SDKs; webhooks.
• Legal friendliness (DPAs, FCRA support for BG, clear liability boundaries).
• Cultural alignment: creator‑friendly, brand‑safe, responsive support.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• Wallet/payment: card, ACH, refund, payouts; tax quotes; receipts hooks.
• Trust: IDV widgets, BG consent flows, FCRA notices; e‑signature for SOW/releases.
• Discovery: social platform connects; metrics ingestion; verified chips.
• Workflow: Drive/Dropbox file manifests; ICS calendar sync; Slack/Zapier notifications.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Standard: pay‑as‑you‑go per‑use fees (IDV/BG); processor % rates; tax quote per‑call; e‑signature per envelope.
• Volume tiers after city 2–3; uptime credits; no minimums in year 1 if possible.
• Co‑marketing exchanges: logo placement, landing pages, co‑webinars, city PR mentions.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Technical: feature flags, city allowlists, fallback paths, incident runbooks.
• Go‑to‑market: co‑branded pages, case studies, launch kits for studios/schools/brands.
• Support & Trust: macros and escalation paths; quarterly business reviews with vendors.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Vendor lock‑in; scope creep; privacy risk; cost overrun; PR misalignment.
• City‑specific regulatory quirks; rate‑limit throttling; API regressions.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Vendor outage → roll to fallback; banner comms; reconcile later; post‑incident credits.
• API change → freeze flag; version pin; contact vendor; hotfix; staged re‑enable.

Owners & RACI:
• Head of Partnerships (DRI), Legal, Security/SRE, Product owners (Money/Trust/Search), City Ops.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Partner‑attributed conversion lift; ACH share; IDV completion; Trusted Pro adoption; studio attach; RFP response rates.
• Cost‑to‑serve per booking by partner; uptime; incident counts; co‑marketing leads.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ Playbooks and fallback paths tested; DPA/SLA signed; partner flags live in staging and one city; dashboards attribute lift.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Quarterly partner pipeline review; 30‑day pilot → 60‑day evaluation → GA or deprecate.

Scenario Playbook — Partner PR misalignment:
Trigger: Partner promotes explicit content conflicting with our artistic‑only stance.
Response: Pause co‑marketing; reassess; require alignment statement; restrict surfaces if needed.
Legal/Comms: Neutral public stance; safety‑first messaging; internal guidance.
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore surfaces after alignment; otherwise sunset integration.
Owner: Head of Partnerships + Trust/Legal | Telemetry: brand sentiment, creator complaints | Evidence: Screenshots, partner campaigns, policy docs

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

§13.1 — Payments, Banking & Tax Partners (Processor, ACH, Payouts, Tax Engine)

§13.1 — Payments, Banking & Tax Partners (Processor, ACH, Payouts, Tax Engine)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Stabilize checkout and payouts with best‑in‑class rails; reduce costs with ACH; keep tax correct with allowlists.
• Ensure reversibility with multi‑processor readiness and clear fallbacks.

Target partner segments:
• Primary processor (card + escrow + payouts); backup processor (failover).
• ACH partner (bank linking, returns handling); payout bank for fast transfers.
• Tax engine for US‑only allowlists; receipt itemization; refund/credit memos.

Mutual value proposition:
• Higher checkout success; lower processor costs via ACH; predictable payouts improve supply retention.
• Tax correctness reduces support noise and financial exposure.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Card + 3DS support; dispute webhooks; idempotent APIs; strong uptime SLAs.
• ACH verification options (instant + micro‑deposits); returns codes; fee transparency.
• Tax engine coverage by state/city; latency; sandbox; post‑outage reconciliation.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• Checkout: card auth/capture, ACH debit, split fees; escrow ledger; refunds; receipts.
• Payouts: bank connect (KYC/KYB); reserves; Early Payout; failure retry; ledger export.
• Tax: quote at checkout; amended receipts; deposit taxation for studios later.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Interchange‑plus or blended %; ACH per‑debit fee; volume tiers after City 2; uptime credits.
• Tax engine per‑call pricing; annual plan negotiated after stability.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Sandbox QA matrices; synthetic test cards and ACH returns; outage drills; status page hooks.
• Buyer ACH discount messaging; deposit vs charge line items; daily close reconciliation playbook.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Processor outage; ACH returns spike; tax misquote; payout queue stuck.
• Vendor lock‑in and unexpected price increases.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Switch to fallback processor; prefer ACH; pause promos; reconcile after.
• Allowlist bypass for affected state taxes; amend post‑recovery; transparent user messaging.

Owners & RACI:
• Payments PM/Eng, Finance, Tax PM, SRE, Support.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Checkout success; ACH adoption; payout latency; settlement variance; tax quote success/latency; dispute win rate.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ 14 days of green daily close; staged rollout in one city; outage drill passed; ACH share ≥ target.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Pilot in Houston alpha/beta; enable in Dallas/Austin after GA stability; quarterly renegotiation checkpoints.

Scenario Playbook — ACH incentive confusion:
Trigger: Buyer fee complaints despite ACH link.
Response: Clarify UI copy; ensure fee reduction applied only on successful ACH; add help‑center article.
Legal/Comms: In‑checkout tooltip; follow‑up email, support macro.
Roll‑back/Forward: N/A
Owner: Payments PM | Telemetry: ACH adoption, buyer fee refunds | Evidence: Screenshots, receipt diffs, support transcripts

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. • Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

§13.2 — Identity Verification, Background Checks & E‑Signature Partners

§13.2 — Identity Verification, Background Checks & E‑Signature Partners

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Increase Instant Book eligibility safely with high IDV completion and optional BG checks; reduce dispute and safety incidents.
• Enable compliant e‑signature for SOW/releases without leaving the platform.

Target partner segments:
• IDV providers (document + selfie checks); BG providers with FCRA workflows; e‑signature vendors with embedded flows.

Mutual value proposition:
• Trust lift → higher conversion; fewer impersonation scams; easier dispute resolution with verified identity.
• Seamless SOW/releases reduce friction and create better evidence for chargebacks.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Accuracy/latency; liveness detection; edge case coverage (lighting, IDs); re‑verification options.
• FCRA compliance (pre‑adverse/adverse notices); adjudication portal; dispute handling; audit logs.
• Signature templates, API, webhook receipts, long‑term storage, and hash verification.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• IDV modal, consent screens, retry flows; badges; 'verified‑only' search filter.
• BG consent; status messaging; Trusted Pro badge; reputation integration.
• E‑signature templates (SOW, releases), per‑booking envelopes; receipts linkback.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Per‑check pricing with volume tiers; subsidies for founding city; credits on false positives.
• E‑signature per‑envelope or monthly pool; usage alerts.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Help‑center copy; sample SOW/release library; appeals instructions; adverse action templates.
• Macros for edge cases (name mismatches; re‑verification; BG disputes).

Top risks & mitigations:
• False declines; user frustration; FCRA errors; cost overrun from high retry rates.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Switch to lighter IDV threshold for non‑Instant Book use; maintain stricter bar for IB.
• Pause BG adjudication if legal notices misconfigured; fix templates; resume.

Owners & RACI:
• Trust lead, Legal, Product (Trust), Support, Data.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• IDV completion; IB adoption; BG pass rate; adverse action timing adherence; dispute rate changes.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ IDV and BG flows pass QA; legal templates reviewed; badges gated; audit logs live; appeals working.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• IDV in Beta; BG rollout optional post‑beta; e‑signature in GA.

Scenario Playbook — IDV false‑positive cluster:
Trigger: Completion drops; reports by specific device/OS
Response: Vendor escalation; adjust thresholds; publish guidance; extend retries.
Legal/Comms: UI hints; support macro; status page if widespread.
Roll‑back/Forward: Revert threshold; schedule root‑cause review.
Owner: Trust/Product | Telemetry: idv_completion, retry_rate | Evidence: Vendor logs, device/OS breakdown

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.

§13.3 — Studios & Locations Ecosystem (Verification, House Rules, Deposits)

§13.3 — Studios & Locations Ecosystem (Verification, House Rules, Deposits)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Create a curated network of verified studios and locations that improve shoot safety and convenience.
• Pilot studio features in a narrow cohort before broader expansion.

Target partner segments:
• Photography/video studios, co‑working creative spaces, community college studios, reputable independent owners.

Mutual value proposition:
• Easier location logistics; safer venues; cross‑promotion; bundled offers with creators.
• Studios gain inbound bookings from our buyer base; we gain supply and co‑marketing.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Legitimate business presence (docs), safety features (access control), clear house rules, insurance.
• Responsiveness to verification and policy alignment.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• Studio verification flow; badge; search filter; house rules; deposit defaults; check‑in/out.
• Studio calendar sync; host messaging; incident reporting; deposit capture/void; receipts.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Standard take‑rate on studio leg when LBG later; initial pilot with flat fees or rev‑share; deposit mechanics with no platform fee on deposit capture.
• Co‑marketing swaps; featuring in city carousels; referral programs.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Studio onboarding kit; sample house rules; safety signage templates; deposit FAQ.
• Partner meetups; photo/video collateral for carousels; studio‑backed creator promo days.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Deposit disputes; misaligned rules; safety incidents; host no‑shows; double bookings.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Deposit claim review; evidence list; capture/partial capture rules; appeals.
• Host support: no‑show resolution, refunds, and rescheduling guidance.

Owners & RACI:
• Studios PM, City Ops, Trust, Support, Finance.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Studio attach rate; dispute rate; deposit claim frequency and outcomes; host/buyer NPS; repeat rate.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ 10–20 verified studios per city; rules and deposit defaults tested; dispute kit functioning; SLAs stable.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Pilot in Houston at or after GA; expand to Dallas/Austin post‑learners.

Scenario Playbook — Deposit claim spike:
Trigger: Claims > threshold in a week
Response: Audit evidence; coach hosts; tune defaults; improve pre‑booking disclosures.
Legal/Comms: Help updates; targeted emails to frequent claimants.
Roll‑back/Forward: Lower deposit amounts temporarily; increase education.
Owner: Studios PM/Support | Telemetry: deposit_claim_rate, claim_outcomes | Evidence: Photos, timestamps, chat logs

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:

§13.4 — Brand & Agency Partnerships (RFPs, Preferred Vendors, Case Studies)

§13.4 — Brand & Agency Partnerships (RFPs, Preferred Vendors, Case Studies)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Attract repeat buyers with RFP tools and preferred vendor lists.
• Lower CAC via partner co‑marketing and showcase case studies.

Target partner segments:
• SMBs with recurring content needs; agencies; DTC brands; local businesses; hospitality and real estate marketers.

Mutual value proposition:
• Brands: curated supply, RFP broadcast, escrow, tax receipts, cost centers, team notes.
• Our platform: steady demand, higher GMV, co‑marketing reach, city credibility.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Budget fit; creative categories; SLA expectations; legal/brand safety requirements.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• RFP creation and broadcast; preferred vendor folders; invoice/PO flows; cost centers; API hooks later.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• No subscription at launch; usage‑based RFP credits; potential volume credits; co‑marketing exchanges.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Brand onboarding: brief templates; case study gallery; team training; dedicated AM for >$10k/mo spend.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Outsized support needs; discount pressure; scope creep; favoritism perceptions.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Pilot with clear SLAs; report deck; mutually agreed KPIs; exit ramp if not a fit.

Owners & RACI:
• Brand Partnerships lead, Growth, Support/AM, Legal.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• RFP volume; response quality/time; conversion rate; repeat spend; CSAT; NPS.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ 3–5 anchor brands per city; RFP pipeline healthy; conversion ≥ targets; co‑marketing content live.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Begin in Beta with 2–3 brands; expand post‑GA; formalize AM tiering later.

Scenario Playbook — Brand requests 'pay‑to‑win':
Trigger: Asks for undisclosed ranking priority
Response: Decline; explain fairness policy; offer Featured slots with labels and caps; educate on filters and RFPs.
Legal/Comms: Written policy and one‑pager; internal alignment.
Roll‑back/Forward: N/A
Owner: Brand lead | Telemetry: brand_satisfaction, provider_feedback | Evidence: Email threads; policy docs

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

§13.5 — Social Platform & Analytics Partners (IG/YT/TT/X/LinkedIn + Analytics Providers)

§13.5 — Social Platform & Analytics Partners (IG/YT/TT/X/LinkedIn + Analytics Providers)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Power verified social metrics, engagement filters, and growth trends with official connections and compliant scopes.
• Phase integration by feasibility and partner access, keeping link‑only options where APIs are closed.

Target partner segments:
• Instagram/Meta for verified metrics; YouTube/Google; TikTok; X (Twitter); LinkedIn (Pages or partner access).
• Third‑party analytics providers with compliant aggregation; link‑only for others.

Mutual value proposition:
• Buyers get confidence in reach/engagement; providers differentiate with verified chips.
• Platform gains unique discovery features and reasons to connect accounts (stickiness).

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• API scope minimalism; rate limits; clear policy; compliance with platform terms; branding rules.
• Ability to refresh nightly + manual refresh; fair use and quotas; stability history.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• OAuth connects; fetch followers, ER, avg views; show verified chips; trend sparklines.
• Advanced metrics (phase 2) for connected accounts only; public discovery within policy bounds.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Typically no direct fees; rate‑limit & review constraints; potential partner programs; compliance costs internal.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Clear 'why connect' copy; low‑friction OAuth; privacy info; disconnect/self‑report options; verified‑only search toggle.

Top risks & mitigations:
• API access changes; policy violations; misinterpretation of metrics; rate‑limit induced outages.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Graceful degradation to self‑reported with 'unverified' label; cache and backoff; communicate transparently.

Owners & RACI:
• Search/Data PMs; Legal; Security; Marketing for co‑marketing approvals.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Connect rates; query usage for social filters; bookings uplift; refresh success; support tickets on metrics.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ Verified chips working; nightly refresh within quotas; help content clear; no policy violations.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Day‑1 IG/YT/TT/X; Phase‑2 LinkedIn if partner access; continuous compliance reviews.

Scenario Playbook — API quota exhaustion:
Trigger: Refresh jobs fail due to rate limits
Response: Backoff; prioritize top accounts; expose manual refresh limits; show stale data banner.
Legal/Comms: Help‑center notice; in‑product tooltip.
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑enable normal cadence after quota reset.
Owner: Data/Search | Telemetry: refresh_success, quota_usage | Evidence: Job logs; API responses

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.

§13.6 — Education & Community Partners (Universities, Trade Schools, Creator Clubs)

§13.6 — Education & Community Partners (Universities, Trade Schools, Creator Clubs)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Seed supply and cultivate best practices via education channels that replenish the marketplace.
• Offer safety training, portfolio reviews, and city meetups that build trust and loyalty.

Target partner segments:
• University photo/video programs; community colleges; trade schools; creator clubs; camera stores; meetup groups.

Mutual value proposition:
• Students and emerging creators get paid experience and safety scaffolds; schools get career outcomes.
• We gain verified, trained supply and grassroots co‑marketing.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• Program legitimacy; faculty champions; safety posture; willingness to co‑host trainings and meetups.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• Campus workshops: Safe‑Mode, deliverables manifest, contracts, reputation; co‑hosted creator days in partner studios.
• Referral codes; verified badges for program participants (non‑monetary recognition).

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Non‑financial in most cases; mutual promotion; event co‑sponsorship; limited grants for founding programs.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Campus starter kit; deck and curriculum; checklist for faculty; event playbook; creator ambassador program.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Overhead vs. ROI; policy misunderstandings; reputational risk if program faces controversy.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Pilot small; measure outcomes; keep content apolitical; focus on craft and safety; pause if controversy arises.

Owners & RACI:
• Community lead, City Ops, Trust, Marketing.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Signups and activation from partner programs; time‑to‑first booking; retention; safety incident rates among cohorts.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ At least 2 partner programs per city; workshops delivered; measurable activation and safety improvements.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Begin in Houston beta; expand to Dallas/Austin; annual refresh of materials.

Scenario Playbook — Low activation from partner school:
Trigger: Few bookings post‑workshop
Response: Follow‑up coaching; pairing with studios; featured carousel for graduates; refine curriculum.
Legal/Comms: Newsletter spotlight; mentor program invitations.
Roll‑back/Forward: Scale back if outcomes remain weak.
Owner: Community lead | Telemetry: activation_rate, time_to_first_booking | Evidence: Attendance, portfolio quality reviews

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.

§13.7 — API & Integration Partners (Zapier, Slack, Drive/Dropbox, Calendar, CRM)

§13.7 — API & Integration Partners (Zapier, Slack, Drive/Dropbox, Calendar, CRM)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free; monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits, and kill‑switches.

Goals:
• Let power users connect our marketplace to their workflows without compromising safety or fairness.
• Start with read‑oriented, narrow scopes; expand only after abuse and privacy reviews.

Target partner segments:
• Zapier/IFTTT; Slack/MS Teams; Google Drive/Dropbox; Google/Apple/Outlook Calendar; Notion/Airtable; Mailchimp/HubSpot for brands.

Mutual value proposition:
• Automations reduce admin toil (e.g., copy bookings to calendar, notify teams, archive deliverables manifests).
• Brands integrate with their CRMs; providers streamline follow‑ups and reviews.

Selection criteria & due diligence:
• OAuth scopes; per‑event webhooks; rate limits; strong ecosystem docs; permissioning and audit logs.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):
• Outbound webhooks for booking events; calendar sync; file manifest export; Slack notifications; RFP broadcast hooks.
• Inbound limited (e.g., RFP create from a brand system) with strict validation and rate limits.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):
• Most APIs free to integrate; paid plans for high call volumes; partner directories for co‑listing.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):
• Developer portal (later); sample zaps; Slack app with scoped permissions; step‑by‑step guides; support forum.

Top risks & mitigations:
• Abuse via automations (spam); privacy leaks via over‑broad scopes; rate‑limit exhaustion; shadow workflows creating support burden.

Operational playbooks (summary):
• Throttle; per‑user caps; approval for certain zaps; audit logs; automated abuse detection; revoke tokens on violations.

Owners & RACI:
• Platform PM/Eng, Security, Data, Support.

KPIs & leading indicators:
• Integration adoption; errors; rate‑limit hits; support tickets; bookings attributed to integrations.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):
✓ Zaps and Slack app pass security review; scopes minimal; abuse anomaly rates low; docs published.

Timeline & checkpoints:
• Post multi‑city GA; staged allowlists; developer portal beta later.

Scenario Playbook — Slack app spam:
Trigger: Automated DMs create spam complaints
Response: Disable outbound DM event; require manual approval; limit to channels; add rate caps.
Legal/Comms: Changelog and help‑center updates; outreach to affected users.
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑enable with stricter scopes after mitigation.
Owner: Platform PM/Security | Telemetry: spam_reports, rate_limit_hits | Evidence: Webhook logs; Slack audit logs

Implementation Notes:
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data principles—only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in §5 dashboards (e.g., ACH share by vendor, IDV completion rate by provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid exclusivity unless compensated; require termination rights, data return/delete clauses, and uptime credits for SLA misses. • City Sequencing: Some partners launch in founding cities only; we gate by city to manage operational readiness. • Accessibility & Inclusion: Ensure partner widgets meet WCAG 2.1 AA; provide text alternatives and keyboard navigation.
• Ethics & Brand Safety: Decline partners whose practices conflict with user safety or our policy posture; include an ethics review in intake.

Appendices A–G

— Begin: Appendices_A_to_G_Combined_v2.docx —

Appendix A — Glossary & Role Map

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
This appendix standardizes the language and responsibilities used across the plan. It prevents ambiguity across product, engineering, trust & safety, support, finance, legal, data, and city ops. It aligns directly with Sections 1 (UX), 3 (Monetization), 4 (Architecture), 5 (Data), 8 (Policies), 10 (Launch), 11 (Risk), and 12 (Roadmap).

A1. Core Marketplace Terms (Plain‑English)

• **Buyer** — The party paying for a service (e.g., photographer hiring a model, brand hiring a creator, or buyer booking a studio in later phases). May be an individual or a business/brand account.

• **Provider / Seller / Talent** — A user offering services (model, photographer, videographer, content creator). A single person can hold multiple roles.

• **Studio Host** — A business or individual offering a physical studio/location for shoots (phase‑gated).

• **Service Profile** — A role‑specific profile (e.g., 'Model', 'Photographer') under one account, each with its own packages, availability, reviews, and pricing.

• **Package** — A priced bundle (time, scope, deliverables) a provider offers. Buyers can add extras and licensing.

• **Instant Book** — Booking flow that does not require explicit provider approval. Requires ID Verification; can be toggled by the provider.

• **Escrow** — Funds held by the platform until completion/acceptance; reduces fraud and enables dispute resolution.

• **Change Order** — A post‑acceptance modification to date/time/scope/price, proposed by either party and accepted by the other.

• **Deliverables Manifest** — A structured list of items the provider commits to deliver (files, counts, formats). We store an immutable external‑link manifest for evidence.

• **Acceptance Window** — Time after deliverables are posted for the buyer to accept or raise issues before escrow releases automatically.

• **LBG (Linked Booking Group)** — A multi‑leg booking (e.g., talent + studio) paid as one transaction with separate receipts. Phase‑gated.

• **Reputation Score** — A 0–100 score derived from reviews, reliability, responsiveness, verifications, and recent performance (role‑aware, time‑weighted).

• **Verified/Trusted Pro** — Badges for ID‑verified users and background‑checked users, respectively.

• **Promoted / Boosted** — Paid visibility units (capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Never override relevance.

• **Safe‑Mode** — Default public content filter for guests. Public surfaces allow only artistic‑grade content; explicit sexual content is disallowed.

• **Boards** — Buyer’s saved shortlists of providers for a project. Board sponsor (later) is a paid placement product.

• **RFP** — Request For Proposal—buyer broadcasts a brief to vetted providers meeting filters.

• **Dispute** — Formal resolution process when either party contests delivery, timeliness, or policy violations.

• **Support Case** — Ticket in the admin console tying user reports, refunds, and moderation actions to a single timeline.

• **City Gate / Allowlist** — Feature flag and supply gating per city to ensure measured rollouts and reversible changes.

A2. Role Map (RACI)

Roles: Buyer/Brand; Provider (Model/Photographer/Videographer/Creator); Studio Host; Support; Trust & Safety; Finance; Tax; Payments; City GM; Growth/Promotions; Product; SRE/Security; Legal; Data.
For each core workflow (search, booking, change order, deliverables, acceptance, dispute, payout, promotions, verification), this map clarifies who is Responsible (doing), Accountable (owning outcome), Consulted (providing input), and Informed (kept aware).

• **Search & Discovery** — Responsible: Product/Search; Accountable: Product; Consulted: Data, Trust; Informed: Support, City Ops

• **Booking & Escrow** — Responsible: Product/Payments; Accountable: Product; Consulted: Finance, Tax, Trust; Informed: Support, City Ops

• **Change Order & Reschedule** — Responsible: Product; Accountable: Product; Consulted: Support; Informed: Finance

• **Deliverables & Acceptance** — Responsible: Product; Accountable: Product; Consulted: Trust/Support; Informed: Finance

• **Disputes** — Responsible: Support; Accountable: Trust; Consulted: Legal/Product; Informed: Finance

• **Payouts & Reserves** — Responsible: Payments/Finance; Accountable: Finance; Consulted: Support; Informed: Trust

• **Promotions (Boost/Featured)** — Responsible: Growth; Accountable: Growth; Consulted: Product/Data/Trust; Informed: Support

• **Verification (IDV/BG)** — Responsible: Trust; Accountable: Trust; Consulted: Legal; Informed: Support

• **Studios (Beta)** — Responsible: Studios PM; Accountable: Product; Consulted: Trust/Legal; Informed: Support/City Ops

A3. Acronyms & Short Codes

S→I (Search→Inquiry) | I→B (Inquiry→Booking) | IDV (Identity Verification) | BG (Background Check) | ER (Engagement Rate) | ACH (Automated Clearing House) | KYC/KYB | PCI | WCAG | RFP | LBG | SOW | PO

A4. Term/Label Canon (UI vs Data vs Legal)

We maintain a canonical mapping of UI labels, data field names, and legal language to avoid drift. Example:
UI: 'Change Order' → Data: change_order_event → Legal: 'amendment'. UI: 'Buyer fee' → Data: buyer_fee_amt → Legal: 'Service fee'.

A5. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Product Ops. Review cadence: quarterly. Change control: PRD + Slack #product‑ops; update Help Center and Admin copy on change.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Appendix B — Data Dictionary (Quick Reference to §5.5)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
This appendix is a field‑level quick reference for analysts and engineers. The authoritative schema lives in the warehouse (Section 5). This guide summarizes Fact and Dimension tables, keys, privacy tags, freshness, and common joins, so product and support can communicate unambiguously.

B1. Naming, Keys & Privacy

Naming: snake_case for tables/columns. Facts store events/transactions; Dimensions store entities/attributes.
Keys: surrogate keys with id prefixes (user_id, booking_id). Foreign keys explicit. Composite keys where necessary.
Privacy tags: P0 (PII‑sensitive like TIN), P1 (contact), P2 (behavioral), P3 (public). Access controlled per §4.14.1.

B2. Core Dimensions

• **user_dim** — User account and global settings.
Fields: user_id (PK), created_at_ts, email_hash (P1), phone_hash (P1), country_code, state_code, city, role_flags, idv_status, trusted_pro_status, rep_overall_score, deletion_status

• **service_profile_dim** — Role‑specific offerings.
Fields: service_profile_id (PK), user_id (FK), role_type ('model'|'photographer'|'videographer'|'creator'), headline, rate_min, rate_max, instant_book_enabled, nsfw_opt_in, studio_verified_flag, rep_role_score

• **location_dim** — Geo lookup.
Fields: location_id (PK), city, state_code, lat, lng, metro_area, timezone

• **time_dim** — Calendar/time grain.
Fields: time_id (PK), date, week, month, quarter, year, dow, hour

• **studio_dim (beta)** — Studios/hosts.
Fields: studio_id (PK), owner_user_id (FK), name, address_hash (P1), verified_flag, deposit_default_amt, house_rules_version

B3. Core Facts (Events/Transactions)

• **booking_fact** — One row per booking request/acceptance/completion.
Fields: booking_id (PK), buyer_user_id, provider_user_id, service_profile_id, role_type, location_id, created_time_id, state ('requested'|'accepted'|'completed'|'disputed'|'canceled'), subtotal_amt, travel_fee_amt, buyer_fee_amt, provider_fee_amt, tax_amt, payment_method ('card'|'ach')

• **booking_leg_fact (LBG)** — One row per leg (talent/studio) in group bookings.
Fields: leg_id (PK), booking_id (FK), leg_type ('talent'|'studio'), leg_subtotal_amt, leg_tax_amt, deposit_auth_amt, accept_time_id, complete_time_id

• **payment_fact** — Charges/refunds.
Fields: payment_id (PK), booking_id, charge_amt, refund_amt, processor, 3ds_flag, ach_flag, status

• **payout_fact** — Provider/host payouts.
Fields: payout_id (PK), user_id, amount, reserve_withheld_amt, reserve_released_amt, early_payout_fee_amt, status

• **tax_quote_fact** — Tax engine responses.
Fields: tax_quote_id (PK), booking_id, state_code, jurisdiction_code, quote_amt, latency_ms, success_flag

• **promotion_impression_fact** — Paid card impressions.
Fields: impression_id (PK), service_profile_id, placement, qs_score, bid_cpc, city, timestamp, buyer_session_id

• **promotion_click_fact** — Clicks on promoted cards.
Fields: click_id (PK), impression_id (FK), ctr_position, valid_click_flag, cpc_charged_amt

• **conversion_fact** — Inquiry/booking conversions attributed to impressions.
Fields: conversion_id (PK), booking_id, attributed_impression_id, incrementality_cell, roas

• **message_fact** — DM events.
Fields: message_id (PK), thread_id, sender_user_id, receiver_user_id, message_type, contains_link_flag, moderation_flag

• **dispute_fact** — Dispute lifecycle.
Fields: dispute_id (PK), booking_id, reason_code, evidence_items_count, decision, time_to_decision_days

• **moderation_fact** — Content moderation outcomes.
Fields: moderation_id (PK), user_id, content_type, action, reason, appeal_flag, final_decision

B4. Joins & Common Queries

Examples: profile discovery funnel; promotions ROAS; dispute loss rate; payout latency by role. Include sample SQL patterns and caution about double counting.

B5. Freshness & Quality SLOs

Gold tables freshness ≤ 15 min for events, ≤ 24h for aggregates. Data quality gates: completeness, uniqueness, referential integrity.

B6. Ownership & Change Control

Owners: Data team. Schema changes require RFC; version notes; downstream impact analysis.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Appendix C — Policy Templates (SOW, Releases, House Rules, Adverse Action)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
Provide neutral, plain‑English templates that users and staff can adopt. These are not legal advice. They must be reviewed by counsel before publication. Where FCRA applies (background checks), we include pre‑adverse/adverse action letter templates and timing notes.

C1. SOW (Statement of Work) — Template

Sections: Parties; Date/Location; Scope; Deliverables (manifest); Usage/License; Fees/Deposits; Changes/Overtime; Travel; Cancellations; Safety & Conduct; Confidentiality; Dispute Resolution; Signatures.
Notes: Keep role‑agnostic; insert exhibit for role specifics (e.g., photo retouch counts, video cuts).

C2. Model Release — Template

Plain‑English clauses: Consent; Scope of Use; Duration; Territory; Compensation; Credit; Revocation limits; No moral rights; Safety; Age of Majority declaration; Witness line. Includes fields to attach IDV reference ID (not storing the ID itself in the document).

C3. Property/Studio Release — Template

Clauses: Permission to use premises; Areas allowed; Time windows; Restrictions (nudity policy compliance); Insurance; Indemnity; Damages; Deposit rules; House rules; Signatures.

C4. House Rules (Studio) — Template

Structure: Safety; Fire exits; No smoking/vaping; Sound limits; Maximum occupancy; Cleanliness; Allowed props; Pet policy; Nudity policy; Neighbor respect; Overtime fees; Deposit conditions; Contacts for emergencies.

C5. FCRA Letters (Background Checks) — Templates

Pre‑Adverse Action: Notice, copy of report, summary of rights, time to respond (e.g., 5 business days).
Adverse Action: Final decision, reasons, reporting agency contact, rights to dispute, no decision by agency disclaimer.
Timing notes: Timer starts when user receives the notice; admin console tracks deadlines (see §4.14.3).

C6. Publishing & Versioning

Owner: Legal/Trust. Version control: numbered exhibits. City deltas: callouts. Accessibility and plain‑language review required.

• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.

• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Implementation Notes:
