Appendix D — City Scoring Model (Expansion Readiness)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
Provide an objective method to evaluate new cities for expansion, avoiding hype‑driven decisions. The model aligns with Section 2 GTM and Section 12 roadmap gates. It produces a composite score with go/no‑go recommendations, data sources, and staffing implications.

D1. Scoring Axes & Weights (Example)

• **Supply Depth (30%)** — Active creators/providers per 10k population; studio partners; education partners; social presence.

• **Demand Potential (25%)** — Local ad spend proxies; SMB density; DTC presence; content‑hungry verticals.

• **Unit Economics (20%)** — CPC expectations; estimated take‑rate GMV; tax complexity; payment costs.

• **Operational Readiness (15%)** — Moderator/Support availability; local studio partners; legal comfort.

• **Competitive/PR (10%)** — Competitor presence; partnership opportunities; press friendliness.

D2. Data Sources & Collection

Internal: waitlists, signups, search traffic, conversion in adjacent cities. External: census data, business registries, ad spend proxies, social trend indices.

D3. Score Calculation & Thresholds

Normalize each axis to 0–100; apply weights; composite score ≥ 70 → consider Beta; 60–69 → nurture; < 60 → defer. Add qualitative notes.

D4. Decision Packet Template

One‑pager with score, map, supply heatmap, top partners, risks, staffing, budget, PR plan, and a proposed launch window.

D5. Governance & Review

Quarterly review; Section 11 risk sanity check; Section 9 budget alignment; Section 10 playbook readiness.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Appendix E — Revenue Recognition Notes & Fee Math Examples (ties to §3.1)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
Document how platform fees are recognized under a marketplace model, how refunds and adjustments are treated, and provide clear numerical examples that match receipts (§4.12) and fee engine rules (§3.1). Coordinate with accounting counsel for GAAP compliance. This is not accounting advice.

E1. Revenue Streams & When Recognized

Provider fee (commission) — recognized at the point the service is delivered and accepted (or auto‑accepted). Buyer service fee — recognized at transaction processing; refunded on provider‑fault cancellations per policy. Promotions revenue — recognized on delivery of impressions/clicks or over the weekly term for Featured.

E2. Escrow, Refunds, Adjustments

Escrow liability sits until acceptance; change orders adjust the contract value; refunds reduce recognized revenue if already recognized; otherwise release liability.

E3. Worked Examples (Step‑by‑Step)

• **Example A** — Talent booking $600; buyer fee 5%; provider fee 12% minus Instant Book 1% and Trusted Pro 0.5%; ACH used; show journal entries for charge, escrow, acceptance, payout, fees.

• **Example B** — Change order +$100; acceptance delayed; buyer cancels under rules; compute partial refund and fee impact.

• **Example C** — Dispute resulting in 30% refund post‑acceptance; show revenue adjustment and payout clawback if applicable.

E4. Journal Entry Patterns (Illustrative)

Include debits/credits for cash, escrow liability, revenue (provider fee, buyer fee), processor fees, promotions, refunds/chargebacks, reserves, early payout fees.

E5. Reconciliation & Controls

Daily close checklist; settlement variances; dispute fees; promotions credits; tax memos.

E6. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Finance. Review cadence: monthly with Section 9; sync with §4.12 ledger outputs and exports.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Appendix F — Tax Nexus Matrix Snapshot (ties to §4.12/§5.10)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
Provide the structure of our tax nexus and taxability matrix without hard‑coding rates or legal conclusions. This appendix explains how the matrix is maintained, how the tax engine allowlist works, and how Support communicates tax outcomes. It is a guide, not legal advice.

F1. Matrix Structure (Template)

Columns: State; City/County; Taxability of services (talent, studio, digital deliverables); Marketplace facilitator obligations; Sourcing rule (origin/destination); Registration status; Effective date; Notes/links. Values are maintained in Admin by Tax role and published to the tax engine allowlist.

F2. Change Control & Reviews

Quarterly review with counsel; engine sync logs; reconciliation variances trigger investigation; audit trail stored in Admin (§4.14.7).

F3. Support Macros & Receipts Language

Plain‑English explainer for buyers: when and why taxes appear; ACH discount messaging; amended receipt process for state‑level changes.

F4. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Tax & Compliance. Acceptance: zero reconciliation variances beyond tolerance; clear help‑center entries; training complete.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Appendix G — Experiment Pre‑Registration Template (ties to §5.13)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose
Create a repeatable, auditable template for experiments that affect discovery, pricing, messaging limits, or safety thresholds. Pre‑registration reduces bias ('p‑hacking') and aligns teams on guardrails and success criteria before launch.

G1. Template Fields

• **Title & ID** — Experiment name and tracking ID.

• **Owner & Reviewers** — Product, Data, Trust, Finance sign‑offs.

• **Hypothesis** — Falsifiable statement including target segment and expected direction of effect.

• **Primary Metrics** — Exactly one or two (e.g., S→I, I→B, dispute loss rate). Defined in §5 catalog.

• **Guardrail Metrics** — Must not degrade (e.g., organic S→I, buyer hide rate, safety reports, payout latency).

• **Population & Randomization** — Eligibility, stratification (city/role), unit of assignment, holdout size.

• **Sample Size & Power** — Pre‑computed; expected duration with traffic estimates.

• **Treatments** — What changes and what remains constant; screenshots/copy.

• **Instrumentation** — Events, experiment bucketing, attribution windows.

• **Analysis Plan** — Statistical tests, treatment of outliers, sequential monitoring rules.

• **Stop/Extend/End Criteria** — Numerical thresholds; min runtime; quality checks.

• **Rollout Plan** — Flags, cities, staged ramp, rollback recipe.

• **Comms Plan** — Internal release notes; help‑center changes; external messaging if any.

• **Risks & Ethics** — Identify bias risks, fairness, and user harm; mitigation.

• **Post‑Mortem Checklist** — What worked, what didn’t, what to productize.

G2. Example (Promotions Density Cap A/B)

Outline a worked example with metrics (ROAS ≥ 2.5×) and guardrails (organic S→I no worse than −3%). Include holdout cell and city gating.

G3. Storage & Discoverability

All pre‑regs stored in the warehouse (Gold) and mirrored in the Admin experiments registry; searchable by owner, city, and metric.

G4. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Data Science. Acceptance: no experiment ships without a pre‑reg; post‑mortems added within 7 days of completion.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Implementation Notes:

• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.

Implementation Notes:
• Keep this appendix version‑controlled; link to the controlling owner and next review date.
• Align terminology with Section 1 UI labels and Section 5 metrics catalog; avoid synonyms that confuse staff.
• When examples include numbers, ensure they reconcile to Section 3.1 fee math and Section 4.12 receipts.
• Accessibility: all templates should be usable with keyboard‑only navigation and screen readers.
• Privacy: avoid embedding real PII in examples; use placeholders consistently.
• City‑gates: where content varies by city, call out the delta explicitly and tie to the corresponding feature flag.
• Training: every appendix should have a 1‑page executive summary and a 'how to use this' section for Support/Trust.
• Change control: every material change requires an entry in the changelog, owner sign‑off, and a Slack announcement to the relevant channel.
